Title: State licensing board puts local neurologist on probation
Abstract: According to the board, Bobker prescribed his girlfriend, who is now his wife, olanzapine, an antipsychotic drug typically used to treat schizophrenia but that can cause drowsiness. The board lifted Bobker’s suspension and placed him on probation for five years, requiring him to be monitored, get psychiatric care and cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia, undergo a neuropsychological evaluation and practice medicine with at least one other licensed doctor. The board said it would immediately suspend Bobker’s medical license if he tests positive for alcohol or any drug not prescribed to him, if he prescribes medication to himself or a family member or if he obtains medication fraudulently.

Title: Ewan McGregor pulls double duty as brothers with issues in 'Fargo'
Abstract: The Scottish actor's voice shifts, taking on the cheery lilt and butter-thick coating of vowels of the distinctive Minnesota accent he's been refining in recent months for his turn in FX's "Fargo.McGregor's vocal - and physical - transformation is on full display with the third-season rollout, which premiered Wednesday, of Noah Hawley's riff on the Coen brothers' 1996 dark, absurdist classic.[...]McGregor, 46, is bringing double the trouble with his first foray into series television in the U.S. In "Fargo," he plays two brothers who've ended up on opposite ends of the Midwestern middle-class hierarchy:Emmit Stussy, the good-looking real estate magnate (a.k.a. the "Parking Lot King" of Minnesota), and his younger, more flabby and balding parole officer brother, Ray Stussy.In the other, he revisited the heroin-addicted slacker Mark Renton for a sequel to 1996's "Trainspotting.[...]he hadn't seen the first two seasons of "Fargo" because, as he tells it, he thought "it was a terrible idea to make a TV series based on a movie."[...]that night at dinner, he ordered dessert.[...]McGregor required roughly two hours' makeup, two prosthetic pieces (a nose piece and a double chin), and a receding-hair wig when playing Ray.[...]he had what he deems a "Spanx technician" - a role assumed by Devora Brown, who worked in the series costume department - to help him slink into the form-sculpting body suit while playing Emmit.

In February, MMC sent a report to the state board. MMC officials reported that Godara had been dropped from its cardiology program in September 2015 "for unprofessional behavior and for violating the terms of her May 2014 probation." As part of her probation since May 2014, she had been barred from "moonlighting," according to the agency documents. In September 2015, CMMC told MMC's cardiology fellowship program director that Godara had been working at the Lewiston hospital and was expected to start working in cardiology there beginning in January; CMMC officials were seeking documentation regarding Godara's participation in MMC's cardiology program.

Title: Rumford lawyer appeals probation
Abstract: He objects to the requirement that he stop litigation, writing in his petition that his law practice is "exclusively litigation," and arguing that the "panel seemed not to realize the ramifications of its de facto suspension as it mistakenly stated in its order that ([Seth Carey]) could focus on the non-litigation portion of his practice." Carey referred to the panel's order to refrain from representing clients in litigation as a "troubling and damaging error" and wrote that the panel's order would result in his "law practice and reputation being essentially destroyed beyond repair." In his dissent, Chairman Peter Fessenden said his chief concerns were Carey's "insulting and ineffective ad hominem attacks on witnesses that persisted despite repeated rulings from the chair that they had no relevance to the issues presented in this case," and "a steady flow of bizarre pleadings and pretrial motions that betrayed a profound disregard of due process and applicable procedures under the Maine Bar Rules."

Title: Rumford lawyer put on probation for competency concerns
Abstract: One judge observed: "there 'was a fair piece of real estate between the lower end of competence and (Attorney [Seth Carey]'s) performance,' and that he was 'close to the bottom of the barrel' of all lawyers he had seen," according to the report. A complaint brought by one of the judges questioned Carey's competence to handle criminal matters in her courtroom. In the earlier suspension, Maine Supreme Judicial Court Associate Justice Andrew Mead ordered Carey to "demonstrate that he has undertaken further education in trial advocacy and professional ethics" before he could be reinstated. Title: Mentally ill are being outsourced to police
Abstract: In its analysis of 2015 police shootings, the Post found dozens of cases where the police were called as a means of getting treatment. Shirley Marshall Harrison called the Dallas police when her schizophrenic, bipolar son was out of control. He was shot down while allegedly charging police with a screwdriver. "I didn't call for them to take him to the morgue," she said of the cops. "I called for medical help." "There are less than 100,000 seriously mentally ill in psychiatric hospitals being cared for by the mental health system," D.J. Jaffe, the executive director of Mental Illness Policy.Org, writes. "But there are 365,000 incarcerated. There are also 770,000 on probation or parole and 165,000 homeless." With the mental-health industry essentially abdicating when it comes to the severely mentally ill who refuse treatment or are too sick to realize they need it, the responsibility of the police is increasingly to serve, protect -- and deal with desperately ill, irrational people. In 2013, the Arizona Daily Star reported that police in Tucson received "more calls about mental illness than about burglaries or stolen cars."

Title: When the time doesn't fit the crime
Abstract: There is a man sitting in a prison in Florida, serving a life sentence without parole, with a first-degree murder conviction on his rap sheet. Title: Man angry state police went to wrong home in late-night probation check
Abstract: "They called, 'State police! Come out with your hands up!'" he said earlier this week. "I don't know if I got paranoid or just angry, but I challenged them. 'Who the hell are you?' Am I going to get tazed? Am I going to get shot by somebody?'" "The next thing I know, I have a cop on the phone. He said, 'Put your firearm down and come out with your hands up,'" Page recalled. "If they had turned on a blue light, I would have known right off quick that they were police officers and acted accordingly. What bothers me is that they didn't listen to anything I said and took it for granted that I was some kind of outlaw." "I want an apology. How many other people have had this happen to them and not spoken up?" he asked. "I'm a citizen here. If I make mistakes, I have to apologize. Why can't the state police apologize to me? That's not too much, for the trauma they're putting me through. What if I'd collapsed, had a heart attack, at my age and with my health?"

Title: Otisfield sex offender arrested for going on school trip
Abstract: [Shawn Lambert] said students were encouraged to bring family members. [Rodney A. Heath] is the uncle of a student at the school, Lambert said. Heath went on school grounds, Lambert said, which was a violation of his parole conditions, and boarded a school bus. Lambert said he signed in simply as "Uncle Rod," which he said was common for informal trips. "He was volunteering, but he wasn't necessarily volunteering for the school," Lambert said. "We do have a school volunteer policy." He said regular class trips conduct background checks on parents who sign up as chaperons. He said Heath wasn't a chaperon. Heath is being held without bail, and Wayne Sturdivant of the Maine Department of Corrections has signed a motion to revoke Heath's probation. According to Sturdivant's statement, on Oct. 10 Heath was terminated from sex offender counseling "for unsatisfactory participation in counseling. The counselor further stated that he believes Mr. Heath presents a danger to public safety," Sturdivant wrote.

Title: Maine makes public new database of inmates and felons on probation
Abstract: "If I had committed a crime when I was 18 and now I was 26 and was sober and got my life back together but was still on probation, all of that [information] would be accessible now and would prevent me from getting gainful employment or becoming recognized as a positive influence in my community," [Judy Garvey] said Tuesday. "It's a civil liberties question here. I think this is very scary." "Lots of states have [these databases], but it's shocking to us in Maine because it's new. Our concern about this database or any registry like this is that it could be a barrier to reintegration," said Zachary Heiden, ACLU of Maine's legal director. "Most people in prison are someday going to be out of prison and we want them to be able to lead productive law-abiding lives. If people are ostracized and unable to find jobs or places to live it will be that much harder for them to lead responsible normal lives." "[Not all of the] 2,000 felons in the area are all bad people -- some are effective members of society. Others will continue to recycle into our facilities over and over and over," [Glenn Ross] said. "A lot of people are embarrassed about what's happened in their life and this makes it hard, but sex offenders have to register, this is a consequence of their actions and the public has a right to know."

Title: Engaged couple's differences are cause for needed pause
Abstract: We have differences when it comes to handling money, keeping the house in order and having pets. We also argued about a pre-nup agreement. [Seth] won't change his position on it and I'm still resentful. I'm worried that if we live together I'll end up with his debts. If things don't work out, I don't want to start all over again. I don't want him around my children or any of my mom's other grandchildren. Mom says he's a reformed person now. He may be, but I don't know him well. Mom is welcome to see my children anytime, but not with him. She thinks I'm being unreasonable, and I'm uncomfortable about the way she is pressing the issue. What should I do? -- CAN'T BACK DOWN ON THIS ONE DEAR CAN'T BACK DOWN: Stand firm in your resolve until such time as YOU are convinced the "perfect man" will not offend again. Your mother is emotional about him and is not thinking clearly. If he had leveled about the fact he's on parole and for what, that would be one thing. But he didn't, and that is cause for worry.

Title: Computer firm sued over worker's murder

During her dinner break on the evening shift, Dwyer followed [Missy Cassella] outside to a metal footbridge, the suit says. He "grabbed Cassella, spun her around, touched her breasts and attempted to kiss her by forcing his tongue into her mouth." She kneed him in his groin and ran back to the call center, the suit says. Instead of reporting the incident to Dwyer's parole officer and local police, ACS conducted an internal investigation, concluding that there was "nothing that could be done to address Cassella's complaint." She was told that Dwyer "had a reputation with the ladies," the suit says.

Title: No equivocation allowed for sexual predators
Abstract: We have all been duly appalled by her story, of course: she was a sun-kissed 11-year-old from South Lake Tahoe who was snatched in 1991 before her stepfather's horrified eyes. She was rescued last week, a 29-year-old woman who has spent the intervening 18 years living in a shabby warren of tents, tarps and sheds in the back yard of her captors, registered sex offender Phillip Garrido and his wife, Nancy. Maybe you think the most horrific part of this story is that Dugard allegedly bore two children by Garrido, the first born when she was about 14. Maybe you think it's that authorities could have rescued her three years ago - neighbors called 911 to report children living in the back yard - but failed to do so. Maybe you think it's the 18 years of life and education (Garrido did not allow her to go to school) she lost, irretrievably. Maybe you think it is her psychological ruination. All that is heart-tearing, I agree. But what gets me is that Garrido should never have been on the street in the first place. When he allegedly took Dugard, Garrido was on parole for the 1976 rape and kidnapping of a young woman. For this, he was given a 50-year federal sentence and - the crime crossed state lines - a life sentence in Nevada.

"We've worked very hard to bring the facilities up to snuff, but it's going to cost more money than we possibly have to do it with." Grant said the school officials had worked hard to overcome the NEASC's concerns during its last re-accreditation review related to curriculum and facilities. While the school system worked hard to improve its curriculum standards, Grant said that the NEASC report essentially called for a new high school or major renovations to the existing building. Title: Felon from Florida opposes extradition
Abstract: [Troy Carroll Vaughan] was convicted in 1992 of two counts each of attempted first degree murder with a firearm, kidnapping, robbery with a firearm, and grand theft, as well as one count each of armed burglary of a dwelling with a firearm and aggravated battery. He was sentenced to 30 years in prison and paroled in October 2007. Defense attorney John Jenness Jr. said Vaughan was opposed to a condition of extradition that releases all persons involved in his apprehension. Vaughan, who is accused of leaving Florida in October without notifying his parole officer of his whereabouts, was arrested in Brownfield in January by deputies from the U.S. Marshals Service and Oxford County Sheriff's Office. "I challenge the state's, or any agency's, legal ability and tactics in detaining my person," Vaughan wrote. "How can you stop a vehicle, which is not making any operable violations, and then arrest a passenger without even asking for identification?"

According to Maine law, a judge may grant bail to people charged as fugitives from justice except in certain circumstances. Title: Criminal justice program begins this fall at CMCC
Abstract: "Introduction to Criminal Justice" (CRJ 101) will be held from 12:30 to 1:55 p.m. Mondays and Wednesdays or 6 to 8:55 p.m Wednesdays. "Introduction to Corrections" CRJ 110 will run from 2 to 3:25 p.m. Mondays and Wednesdays. The course is designed to provide an overview of the historical background of corrections. Topics will include the goal and purposes of corrections; the various past and current philosophies of corrections; the concepts and issues that determine the necessity for the development of the Maine Correctional Standards; the legal issues in corrections; the principles of constitutional law as it pertains to the 1st, 4th, 8th and 14th Amendments and the rights of inmates; the structure and functions of incarceration; probation and parole agencies; and management and treatment programs.

Title: Forum: Funding cuts may backfire
Abstract: The cuts, $200 million to MaineCare alone, are huge, said Richard Batt, Franklin Memorial Hospital's president. DHHS, as directed by the governor, has to recommend cuts to balance the budget, said Kathy Bubar of DHHS. Bubar also described federal rule changes that would affect case management of people in child protective services, parole and probation and some special education services. Changes also would require more record keeping, taking time from client care. Batt said that unless there is congressional intervention, the federal changes will happen and went on to encourage people to contact Maine's U.S. senators and members of Congress as well as state legislators.

Title: Monitoring MySpace can help catch predators ; It is important, however, that access to the Web site by law enforcement not be open-ended.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: The concern is warranted. Authorities in Texas recently arrested seven convicted sex offenders who had MySpace profiles. The Michigan attorney general's office reported finding about 200 registered sex offenders, including 28 on probation or parole, who had MySpace accounts. The Web site, for its part, in early May began using software to identify and remove sex offenders. About 17,000 accounts have been dropped to date. In Maine, Attorney General Steve Rowe obtained an order from Kennebec County Superior Court, demanding that MySpace turn over the names, e-mail addresses and identifying computer information of registered sex offenders from Maine who have profiles on the site. Rowe also seeks the identification of Maine sex offenders whose profiles have been deleted.

Title: Druggist placed on probation
Abstract: The Board of Pharmacy ruled in August 2005 that [Joey McLafferty] had violated 10 of the 12 federal and state pharmacy rules for which he was initially cited. The board fined McLafferty $10,700 with all but $4,000 excused and held him responsible for $3,500 for costs of the two-day hearing. It also required him to abstain from consuming alcohol, undergo random alcohol testing and continue seeing a substance abuse counselor until Feb. 6, 2006. They also agreed to issue a letter of reprimand for failing to establish and maintain effective controls to prevent errors or misfills and to issue a letter of guidance on alcohol use during business hours. A substance abuse counselor testified at the hearing that McLafferty didn't abuse alcohol and wasn't dependent on it.

Title: Nokomis retains accreditation after 3-year probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: NEWPORT - Nokomis Regional High School has just learned that its accreditation has been retained and, in a flip-flop from the last assessment that listed 61 deficiencies, was commended in 17 areas. [Arnold Shorey] said the school's accreditation was retained after NEASC reviewed the school's five-year report and found that enormous changes have taken place in the past year. SAD 48 is undergoing a reorganization and the fate of Nokomis is part of that plan. Shorey said the state is going to hold all funding of new schools for one year to build up the funding pool and that when it recommences, Nokomis should be in the top three. "Should we get funded, a new school wouldn't be completed for five or six years after that."

The probation does not affect athletic recruiting or post- season tournament play, but it does mean the athletic department must stay clean during the period and comply with an NCAA audit. The athletic department relies on a large number of students to assist with operations at the athletic complex. At the time of the infractions, 175 students worked in various jobs. Title: When is a sex offender not a risk to community? ; Local law enforcement agencies act differently in the case of a man who served 20 years in prison.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: The Portland Police Department, which has historically been aggressive about sex offender notification, investigated [Richard Brusgulis]' criminal record when he moved to the city three years ago. His record shows he was twice convicted of assault with intent to rape against women older than 25, the last incident being in 1985. Police determined no notification was necessary. Since then, Brusgulis has never failed to keep his registry information up to date, unlike some offenders, said Portland Deputy Chief William Ridge. The sheriff's department, which has jurisdiction where Brusgulis works, initially assessed him as a moderate risk. But some extra digging by investigators came up with information about his juvenile record and other charges that did not result in convictions. That changed Brusgulis' score on a risk assessment sheet to a "7" - with six or above being high-risk. Brusgulis was convicted in Massachusetts of a 1985 pre-dawn attack on a 40-year-old jogger on a path near the Charles River in Watertown. In recommending a sentence of 18 to 20 years, prosecutors noted that when Brusgulis was arrested in the attack, he was on parole for a similar attack in 1982.

Title: The HookUp: Stop. Go. Slow down. Read the signals.
Abstract: Here's an example. A fairly intelligent dating columnist we know had a crush on a man who wore a ring. It was a wedding band, actually, which he wore on the middle finger of his left hand. What followed was months of agonizing over whether he was trying to be shady about his marital status or if he really had no clue that any sane woman would immediately zero in on the wedding band on his left hand. Clothing. According to the unspoken stereotype, most well-dressed men are usually gay, while most of the hat-to-the-side, skullcap-saggy-pants wearers are usually on parole. This stereotype is utterly false; we understand why clues from clothing can be misleading. If you pick us up for dinner looking like an old-school Flavor Flav wannabe, you'll have to forgive us for slamming the door in your face.

Title: Death of Hmong hunter has Wisconsin on edge
Abstract: Authorities detained a 28-year-old Peshtigo man, James Nichols, who showed up at a medical center Saturday with a gunshot wound that wasn't life-threatening, said Laurel Steffes, a spokeswoman for the Marinette County Sheriff's Department. He is considered a person of interest but was being held on a parole violation from an unrelated burglary conviction and had not been charged in Vang's death, she said. Dealings between the Hmong, an ethnic minority group from Southeast Asia, and predominantly white residents of the mostly rural north woods have been on edge since November 2004, when Hmong immigrant Chai Soua Vang, 38, of St. Paul, Minn., killed six white hunters and injured two while trespassing in a private tree stand. Even before those shootings, Hmong hunters claimed they had been harassed, and whites complained that the Hmong do not respect private property.

Title: Judge bars man from possessing porn or panties ; A convict's peculiar criminal past prompts a judge toset special probation conditions.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: "Mr. [Nicolas R. Leathers] has some mental health issues as is typical in the court system, and the tough thing is he was previously convicted for sex offenses," said Kevin Sullivan, Leathers' attorney. "Once somebody commits a crime that gets him on the (Maine Sex Offender) registry, the help doesn't exist. ... People like Nicolas need help and it's not available. They're the outcasts of society." Other probation conditions added Thursday bar Leathers from the use and possession of sexually explicit material and pornography and order him to participate in a psychological evaluation once he is released from custody. He is subject to search for female undergarments, sexually explicit material and pornography (including computers). Leathers also must abide by a 7 p.m. curfew unless his therapist and probation officer decide otherwise.
Authors: BETTY ADAMS Blethen Maine News Service

[He did] not put it into the gun," the assistant district attorney said. McLellan's attorney, Carol Lewis of Lubec, said that her client had taken responsibility immediately. She said he did not have a prior criminal record and this was the first such incident. She said McLellan's mother had acted responsibly and removed all guns from the house. She said the mother also has sought counseling for her son. "He is an excellent probation candidate," she told the judge. He suggested that McLellan's mother apply to Pine Tree Legal for assistance to get her son back in school. "He needs to be in school," [John Romei] said. Title: Why is USM exhibiting 'art' produced by a convicted killer? ; Thomas Manning's claim to be a 'political prisoner' is an insult to police and all law-abiding citizens.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: [Thomas W. Manning], whose work contains images of "domestic and international political prisoners," has included a self-portrait. Now, USM is at the center of a firestorm focused on the fact that Manning is serving an 80-year term without parole for a series of bombings and the 1981 murder of a New Jersey state police officer. It didn't help things that one of Manning's most prominent defenders is Raymond Luc Lavasseur, a Maine man who served a federal prison term for the same bomb attacks as Manning.

Title: Jailed and jaded
Abstract: While living in New York with his older brother, [Daniel Jackson] failed to report to his parole officer and a warrant was issued for his arrest. Although he was advised against it because of that outstanding warrant, Jackson wanted to come back to Maine where most of his family has lived since 2000. He also wanted to see his girlfriend, who, he said, is pregnant with their child.Confined to jail Dressed in inmate orange, a subdued Jackson sat in a room at the jail Monday talking quietly about his situation. Nearby, a guard stood watch beside a half-wall petition, while the shouting and banging from Jackson's sister, Angela Taylor, disrupted the quiet. Taylor, who is 10 years older than her brother, is also confined to the Franklin County Jail. Jackson's stay at Franklin County jail started in July after police were called to a Wilton apartment complex where someone reported hearing a gun shot. Jackson evaded arrest for a week and has refused to discuss the incident, although he faces charges of terrorizing and reckless conduct with a firearm.
subjectTerms: Jackson, Daniel , Taylor, Angela , Stinchfield, Goyo

Title: Newfield uproar raises serious questions over sex offenders ; The state has a major problem on its hands that a 'two-strikes' law could help address.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: Still, he's served his sentence and is on probation until 2010. The state is paying $1,000-a-week rent on the RV for at least three more weeks, and Corrections Commissioner Martin Magnuson said that more than 300 attempts to find a place for him to stay had been uniformly rejected by landlords. One way to keep first offenders who have served their sentences from being hounded from town to town could be a strong "two-strikes" law. Such a measure would put offenders on notice that first offenses will still draw long sentences, but any similar crimes after that will yield life in prison without parole.

Title: Harlan Sylvester, 71, established fire department at state prison: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: Mr. Sylvester began his career at the prison in 1959 and worked his way up the ranks to become a classification/rehabilitation officer. He worked at the prison for 27 years and was responsible for keeping track of parole dates for inmates. Kay Sylvester said her husband loved his job. Some inmates grumbled, she said, but Mr. Sylvester "made a lot of friends and earned the respect of a lot of people." Mr. Sylvester also volunteered for the local fire department. Retired Fire Chief George Grafton said if there was a fire, Mr. Sylvester would be at the scene all night. Mr. Sylvester is also survived by two daughters. His son-in-law Milton Peabody, of Somerville, N.J., said Mr. Sylvester was a good family man.

Title: RESTRICTING SEX OFFENDERS: [ALL EDITION]
Abstract: Residents in Hampden are concerned that three sex offenders live at the Bangor Rescue Mission, which is located on the Meadow Road in Hampden. Rep. Debra Plowman has filed legislation to ban sex offenders from living together in the same dwelling or in the same multi-unit building. She worries that by living together, offenders can discuss their past crimes, making them more likely to commit new ones. Restrictions also make it difficult for state and local officials to find housing for sex offenders. In California, one offender remained in jail for more than a year after his sentence expired because of restrictions and community outcry. In other parts of the state, offenders were living in cots in a parole office and the state was paying more than $300 a night to house offenders in motels.

Title: SAD 48 eyes Nokomis accreditation hurdles District told portable classrooms must be eliminated to end school's probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: "We have 11 classrooms in portables," [Arnold Shorey] said. "Without a major addition to our building, we physically cannot eliminate those portables. If NEASC continues to insist that we get rid of all our portables, accreditation for Nokomis will become a moot issue." Removing the portables would mean a lack of space for programs such as broadcasting, welding and drafting, as well as the school's print shop. Some of these programs are invaluable for keeping students engaged and challenged in school, [William Braun] said, while waiting for vocational education opportunities that aren't available until 11th grade. Braun said the move by NEASC is aimed at forcing communities to financially support schools, but Nokomis' probation status has not moved the district any higher on the state's priority list for school construction. SAD 48 is 25th on the state's high school replacement list.

Title: Pedophile who collected child porn gets 7 years ; The judge also puts John D. Corbin on probation for 18 years so he'll be supervised.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: [John D. Corbin], 60, of Windham pleaded guilty last month in Cumberland County Superior Court to 131 counts of possessing child pornography and a single count of disseminating it. The Rev. Garvin Warden, former pastor of the Chestnut Street Church, explained how the church was eagerly looking for male volunteers in 1999 to help the women prepare meals for the youth group, and that Corbin responded to that plea. He also said Corbin had been a helpful member of the church community, using his financial skills to help clean up the church's accounting practices. Members of the Chestnut Street United Methodist Church said Corbin's work for the church's youth program, which served largely disadvantaged children, built trust between Corbin and the children that could have been tragic. Title: Staying sober, and still laughing: [All Edition]
Abstract: Eventually, it dawned on me that maybe my way wasn't working anymore. This was during my sixth incarceration, and I was getting sick of doing time. One night, we were crowded into my cell, six or eight of us. I had those guys laughing so hard they were begging me to shut up. After lights out, when things had quieted down a little, I realized I was in a federal penitentiary, with no drugs, no booze, and I had been laughing harder than I had laughed in many, many years. It gave me a tiny bit of hope that maybe I could have fun without drugs and booze. I didn't stay sober at that point, but I never forgot that night. I ended up beating the career criminal charges, but was found guilty of being a felon in possession of a firearm. Instead of 15 years, I served three years in federal facilities, followed by five years on parole. One condition of my parole was to attend at least five 12-step meetings per week. So I would go to four meetings on Saturday and one on Sunday morning and nothing changed. If you took the drugs, booze and crime out of my life, there wasn't much left. I would manage to go six or nine months clean and sober on my own, and I would get to a point where I had no idea who I was. I would feel the emptiness of my life, and before long return to using drugs to try to fill that emptiness. As a result, I ended up violating my parole on four different occasions, which meant a return to prison each time.

Title: Houlton man's probation revoked Judge orders return to jail to finish sentence after alleged theft of morphine pills: [1, 2 Edition]
Abstract: During a probation revocation hearing in Aroostook County Superior Court on Friday, Aroostook County Assistant District Attorney Suzanne Russell told the court that [Robert Cottle] had been out of jail and on probation for about five weeks before he allegedly engaged in new criminal conduct. The victim said that she told Cottle to sit on her porch while she finished talking with her child. Both she and her mother testified that Cottle went to the porch, but later disappeared from sight. Both said that he later stepped hurriedly off the porch with his hands in his pockets and told them that he was going to a nearby residence to visit his grandmother. The victim immediately suspected Cottle, and told the judge that Cottle knew she was taking the medication and had once asked her if he could buy a pill from her. She testified that she refused and Cottle became angry with her.

Title: Aid for young addicts in jeopardy: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Steve] - not his real name - is addicted to opiates. He graduated recently - not from high school, but from his year of participation in Maine's juvenile drug treatment court. It's an experience he says probably saved his life by requiring him to stop using street drugs and keeping him out of the Mountain View Youth Development Center in Charleston, where he thinks his self-destructive attitude and behavior would have become more deeply ingrained. For the past year, [Laurie Aldrich], along with Steve's committed parents, made sure he got to his meetings and appointments, tested his urine and called to make sure he was home when he should be. She's the one who talked with school officials about his behavior in class and his academic performance, and she accompanied him to his weekly meeting, along with half a dozen other youngsters in Bangor's regional program, with Maine District Court Judge Ann Murray. In the current budget debate, what's at risk is the $255,000 funding for caseworkers like Aldrich. Six caseworkers like Laurie Aldrich are employed by the nonprofit, private Day One substance abuse recovery program in Portland. All six work full time in the drug court program. Day One Executive Director David Faulkner said an annual evaluation conducted by the University of Southern Maine shows that youths in the drug treatment court program are less likely to commit crimes or use drugs than their counterparts on probation and parole programs and much less likely than youthful offenders who serve longer terms of incarceration.

Title: Moussaoui trial missteps inspire little confidence ; One can be opposed to the death penalty and still be appalled at this incompetence.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: As a convicted co-conspirator in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, Zacarias Moussaoui represents a test of principle for those who oppose the death penalty. But the arguments against capital punishment - from its irreversibility to its inability to bring back victims - exceed those in favor, even in Moussaoui's case. For prosecutors seeking the death penalty against Moussaoui, [Leonie Brinkema]'s ruling must be something of a relief. Earlier, she had threatened to throw out the government's case entirely, sending Moussaoui to prison for life without the possibility of parole.

Title: Statutes, prior decisions limit murder sentences: [All Edition]
Abstract: The state's 16 Superior Court justices are the men and women who sentence murderers. Not only are they required to follow the sentencing provisions set out in state statutes, they also must fashion sentences that meet the guidelines handed down over the years by the Maine Supreme Judicial Court. "Unlike other states where life means someone could be eligible for parole someday, life means life in Maine," Deputy Attorney General William Stokes, whose office prosecutes all murder cases, said earlier this week. "Life means the convicted murderer will die in prison short of commutation of the sentence or a governor's pardon." Of those who did not receive life sentences, Mark Barnes, 36, of Orono was sentenced to 65 years in prison for murdering his mother, and Carl Wayne Heath, 24, of Fryeburg was sentenced to 40 years for bludgeoning a Bangor cabdriver. Roscoe Sargent, 31, was sentenced to 50 years for stabbing his pregnant wife to death.

Title: Felons and parolees banned from guns still get hunting tags
Abstract: Montana may not be alone. While nearly all states ban felons from possessing guns, only a handful - including Rhode Island and Maine - keep them from receiving hunting permits, and just a few others - such as Illinois and Massachusetts - require hunters to show both a hunting license and a firearms license. The AP examination of Montana hunting and corrections records shows at least 660 felons on parole or probation received tags in the past year. The findings are based on a comparison of unique first, middle and last names, along with other identifiable information, that appeared in databases of both hunters and felons. Colorado, like most states, relies on its law banning felons from possessing guns to discourage them from applying for hunting licenses. Still, every year game wardens find someone with a felony conviction hunting with a firearm and a legally obtained hunting license, said Bob Thompson, assistant chief of law enforcement for the Colorado Division of Wildlife.

Title: Somali leaders question teen's arrest for school bomb threat ; Hamza Hassan's father says his son felt pressured during a police interview and that he didn't confess.: [FINAL Edition]

Hassan told him he felt confused and pressured, Hirsi said. His father posted $290 bail at the Cumberland County Jail the day he was arrested. But Hassan was transferred to Long Creek instead of being released because authorities considered the bomb threat charge to be a violation of parole conditions he was under at the time of the arrest. Hassan had been committed to Long Creek because of juvenile offenses, according to the Cumberland County District Attorney's Office.

Title: For life without parole: [All Edition]
Abstract: Since 1973, 114 persons convicted of capital crimes in the United States have been exonerated. That is roughly one for every 50 convictions. According to some sources, another 38 people were executed despite serious doubts about their guilt.

Title: Probation sentences down, say reports: [All Edition]
Abstract: Judges, prosecutors, law enforcement officials, probation officers, correction officials, defense attorneys and service providers gathered Thursday in Augusta for the Maine Sentencing Institute. It is held every three years to discuss crime, its impact, and how offenders should be dealt with at every level of the system. The law revamping probation rules to create needed space in Maine's overcrowded prisons and jails was passed last spring. It eliminated probation for most misdemeanor offenses. It also gave state corrections officials authority to place some inmates with two years remaining on their sentences in supervised community confinement with time off for good behavior increased from five days to nine days per month. The "good time provision" does not apply to those serving time for murder, sex crimes or domestic violence. "Ideally, probation is a wonderful concept," [Neale Duffett] said, "but in Maine, we killed it by overusing it."

Title: H-2B or Not H-2B: [All Edition]
Abstract: Whether individually or as a group, the loggers meet the parole standard of providing a "significant public benefit," by being allowed in. The fragile condition of the timber industry and the fading paper industry in Maine make any significant disruption a substantial public problem and a solution a significant benefit. And the secretary could avoid setting precedent by observing that loggers, unlike all other H-2B temporary, nonagricultural workers, actually fit more closely with the H-2A immigrant agricultural employees, which do not have a cap. Part of the reform should consider changing the loggers' designation to the agricultural visa classification.
