But an agreement between the governors of Maine and Maryland called for Oken to be extradited so he could face trial and sentencing for the first two murders after receiving a sentence of life without parole in Maine. Oken's 15-day killing spree began near Baltimore in 1987, where he killed [Dawn Marie Garvin] and [Patricia Hirt], and brought him to Maine, where he checked in to the Coachman Motor Inn on Route 1 in Kittery. Ward was working at the front desk. Police found her body in a room behind the check-in area. She had been shot once in the head. Kittery police found a blood-stained shirt in Oken's room, and Maine State Police issued a statewide public alert. Oken was found at the Freeport Inn and surrendered to police, who had surrounded the building. The gun used in Ward's killing was found in his car.
subjectTerms: Oken, Steven , Ward, Lori , Tsintolas, Suzanne , Garvin, Dawn Marie , Hirt, Patricia

Title: Parole board: Inmate killed mother ; The result of Thursday's hearing for David Nelson means he is unlikely to ever be freed from the state prison.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: A concrete and steel meeting room deep in the maximum-security section of the Maine State Prison may be the closest [David Nelson] ever gets to freedom. That's where Maine's five-member parole board found unanimously that Nelson probably smothered his mother to death in 1991, the last time he was out on parole. Nelson, 53, was let go in 1989 after serving 13 years of a life sentence for strangling a retired lawyer in a Portland motel room. Nelson's case will be reviewed periodically in the years to come, but every time that happens, future parole boards will see a one- sentence note in his file declaring the board's unanimous finding: "David Nelson unlawfully caused the death of Natalie Babcock." [Eric Morse] argued that the hearing should not be held at all. He said it was up to officials in Florida, where Babcock was killed, to prove Nelson's guilt to a jury. Morse said Maine officials were convicting his client instead in an informal administrative hearing.
subjectTerms: Nelson, David , Wannemacher, Joseph , Babcock, Natalie , Morse, Eric , VanHouten, John

Title: Police Log - Windham: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Police assisted the Drug Enforcement Agency in the arrest of a 25- year-old Windham man in his home on Shady Lane at 9:29 p.m. He was wanted on a federal charge of tampering with a witness. At noon Windham police responded to a "keep the peace" call at a home on Route 115 and assisted the Department of Probation and Parole in the arrest of a 24-year-old Windham man allegedly drinking alcohol, which violated his parole. An alarm at Windham Veterans Association was triggered at 2:55 a.m. when a rock was thrown through a window.

Title: Parole board to hear 1991 murder case ; If David Nelson is found responsible for his mother's death, he may never be freed from prison.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: [David Nelson] has never been charged with the crime, and prosecutors in Palm Beach County in Florida have said they do not plan to do so. In a letter to detectives, a prosecutor said there was enough evidence to cast "suspicion" on Nelson, but it was not strong enough to win a conviction. That is unfair, said Nelson's lawyer, Eric Morse of Rockland. When the burden of proof is so low, he said, it will be nearly impossible for Nelson to defend himself against 12-year-old charges. The investigation led to Nelson, then 25, who had been seen with [Raymond Hogan] at the Portlander bar shortly before the older man's death. Nelson was tried in April 1976 and convicted. At that time, murder brought an automatic life sentence.
Authors: GREGORY D. KESICH Staff Writer Susan Butler, staff researcher, contributed to this story.
subjectTerms: Nelson, David , Babcock, Natalie , Wannemacher, Joseph

Title: POLICE LOG - Sanford, York, Biddeford, Wells: [York Edition]
Abstract: Abraham Gammon, 30, of Biddeford was arrested on a charge of theft by unauthorized taking or transfer following a shoplifting incident at Sears on Elm Street at 9:40 a.m. Officers say Gammon attempted to flee the scene but they caught up with him. He was taken to York County Jail. Thomas Thyng, 39, of Biddeford was arrested on a charge of assault on Franklin Street at 1:30 p.m. after he allegedly attempted to choke a woman. He was bailed, released and re-arrested a short time later after he attempted to make contact with the woman on three separate occasions, violating his parole, police said. He was taken to York County Jail. Mark Harmon, 29, of Wells was arrested on the Mildram Road following a traffic accident at 12:38 a.m. Officers say Harmon ran his 1994 Datsun pickup truck off the road and into a rock. He then fled the scene. Police caught up with him, charging him with operating a vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating drugs or alcohol, leaving the scene of a property-damage accident and violating his probation. He was taken to York County Jail on a probation hold at his probation officer's request. Harmon was not injured in the accident, but his truck sustained $2,500 in damages.

Title: Giving more life terms can be good for society ; With crime rates dropping, it looks like longer terms are having a good effect.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: With more and more convicted criminals getting life sentences, about 25 percent without even the chance of parole, some observers are questioning whether or not such sentences are being used too often. IN 2003, one in four convicts serving a life sentence was doing so without the chance of parole. These "real" life sentences are outnumbered by sentences where parole is a possibility. Staff photo by John Ewing The new Maine State Prison at Warren: If more criminals convicted of capital crimes or numerous serious felony offenses stay in such places longer, there could be fewer crimes and less total expense to society.

Title: Fort Kent man gets probation in fraud: [All Edition]
Abstract: During 1999, [Gordon Pelletier] hired a few workers to drive logs into Canada. He compensated employees and paid off business loans but did not pay himself a salary, [Terence Harrigan] said Tuesday. When he received a MEMIC employee status report in January 2000, he mistakenly stated that he had not received any benefit from his business in the previous year.

Title: Investigators recount Colby murder probe: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Edward Hackett] had moved back to Maine recently after having been released on parole from a Utah prison. He had served time there for abducting a woman at knife point and sexually assaulting her. The woman, it was later learned, had a hairstyle similar to [Dawn Rossignol]'s and also drove a red car. A police officer interrupted the attack in Utah. Hackett has since admitted to fantasizing about women with blond hair parted in the middle. Back at the crime lab, a forensic chemist swabbed the doors of Rossignol's car, "even though there was nothing there that you could see. DNA has progressed so far that you can get DNA from things you can't even see. In this case, they received a DNA sample from the handle of the car door because he had touched it when he abducted her from the parking lot at Colby. What he left behind was skin cells," [Timothy Doyle] said. When police interviewed Hackett again, [Joe Zamboni] told Hackett about the match and Hackett vomited, confessed and was taken into custody.

Title: Winslow man gets probation in virus scheme case: [All Edition]
Abstract: Walter Gogan, 63, of Winslow also was fined $4,000 by U.S. District Judge John Woodcock. A former lab worker at Maine Biological Laboratories in Winslow, Gogan pleaded guilty last year to being an accessory after the fact to smuggling the virus into the country.

Title: Heroin charges may be dropped: [All Edition]
Abstract: Melendez was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life without parole after a jury-waived trial last month in Pittsburgh. Judge Jeffrey A. Manning ruled that Melendez was mentally competent when he stabbed his mother 36 times in a fight over drugs on Aug. 28, 2002, in West Deer, Pa., a township of 11,500 people just north of Pittsburgh. Defense attorney Kathleen Cribbins had argued that his history of depression from childhood compounded his substance abuse problems so that he was unable to form the specific intent to kill. Melendez's then 13-year-old daughter, Nichole, testified she saw the trouble brewing and hid all the kitchen knives, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported last month. She said she scooped up her 2- year-old brother and cowered in a second-floor room until the fighting stopped.

Title: Student handed 45-day sentence Husson athlete violated probation: [2 Edition]
Abstract: That had been the state's recommendation, worked out between Assistant District Attorney Paul Cavanaugh and David Mitchell, [Morgan Drew]'s attorney. Her original sentence from the state for burglary had been 18 months with all but 30 days suspended. Drew, 20, has about two months more to serve on her federal sentence, including credit for time served. Once she serves the 45 days on her state sentence concurrently, she has no more probation obligations with the state. During her incarceration, Drew has completed her freshman-year coursework for Husson, with a 3.0 grade point average. She has completed applications to transfer to a school in southern Maine to finish her degree, Mitchell told the court.

Title: Panel urges stricter use of probation to reduce state's prison population: [All Edition]
Abstract: One key recommendation would eliminate probation as a sentencing option for most low-level offenders. Probation is the most heavily used sentencing option in most cases, but caseloads topping 140 offenders per probation officer have made it unmanageable, officials said. Probation could still be used for low-level sex offenders, domestic violence offenders and repeat drunken drivers, but would be practically eliminated for other Class D and E misdemeanors. Judges will be encouraged to find other sentencing alternatives, such as community service and restitution. The report also suggests reducing the number of years offenders serve probation. Somerset and Kennebec County District Attorney Everett Fowle, who was on the 17-member commission, wrote in an attached minority report that prosecutors need more alternatives, not fewer, and suggested that eliminating probation for low-level offenders would result in more offenders going to prison.

Title: Sangerville man who stole women's clothing returns to prison: [All Edition]
Abstract: In 1998, [Gregg McInnis] broke into homes in Guilford and Sangerville and stole 139 pieces of women's clothing, including undergarments, swimsuits, prom gowns, men's magazines, photographs and other items. Some of the homes were on his newspaper route. When Dan Dickson, the local probation and parole officer, learned in early March that McInnis was delivering newspapers again, he visited the Sangerville man's home where he found a bag containing women's used and new undergarments and pornography. McInnis' older brother, J.R. McInnis, who is home on leave from the military, also asked the court for leniency. "I have a lot of faith in Gregg," he said. He said he and his brother recently lost their mother to cancer and that their father was suffering from the same disease. J.R. McInnis said he believed that Gregg had taken the additional job to help the family.

Title: Probation, parole, police enjoy shared space: [2, 3 Edition]
Abstract: DOVER-FOXCROFT - Dover-Foxcroft police and local probation and parole officials have found there are perks to their close association. The "marriage" also is a bonus for probation and parole, according to [Dan Dickson] and Deborah Reynolds, juvenile community corrections officer. For Reynolds, who previously rented space in a building used by the Department of Human Services on the eastern side of town, it means a level of protection. Dickson had operated from an office on the western side of town near Foxcroft Academy, a less-than-ideal place to draw sex offenders.

Title: Hackett's life sentence protects Maine families ; If more states followed Maine's 'no parole' policy, the nation would be a safer place.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: [Edward Hackett] himself wanted to live in prison for the rest of his life, and with good reason - this is a man who simply cannot be rehabilitated. In an eerie interview in October, Hackett spoke plainly and in psychologically technical terms about why he attacked [Dawn Rossignol]. It was clear he'd spent his share of time with mental health professionals, and it was frightening that it had had little effect.

Title: Colby student's killer receives life sentence: [All Edition]
Abstract: Both [Pamela Ames] and [William Stokes] agreed that [Edward Hackett] never should have been in Maine at all. The state of Utah transferred his parole here because he wanted to be closer to his parents in Vassalboro. On the morning of Sept. 16, Hackett pulled into a parking lot at Colby and saw Rossignol walking to her car. "He told himself, 'If she is still there by the time I park my car, it's a sign,'" Stokes said.Hackett then forced Rossignol into her car at knifepoint, and they ended up at Rice Rips Road just off campus, where he brutally attacked her and killed her by smashing her head with a rock. In the days after the discovery of Rossignol's body, probation and parole workers immediately began looking at Hackett as a suspect, Stokes said, but it was the thoughtful investigation by the Maine State Crime Lab that sealed the case.
Authors: SHARON KILEY MACK;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: Hackett sentenced to life ; The killer with a long history of mental health issues had asked for a life term in the death of a Colby College student.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Because Maine has no parole, the life sentence means [John Patriquin Edward J. Hackett], who is 47, can never be released. [Donald Marden] also imposed maximum sentences against Hackett for the crimes of kidnapping, aggravated assault and robbery. Hackett said little during the one-hour proceeding in the Kennebec County Courthouse. When Marden asked if he wanted to speak, Hackett stood awkwardly and mumbled a single word. Hackett was charged with abducting a woman at knifepoint at a shopping mall and trying to rape her. In that case as well, Hackett pleaded guilty to kidnapping and robbery, but not the sex crime. He served nine years in prison after spending two years in a state mental hospital.

Title: Hackett attorney: Expect action ; The case of a man accused of a Colby College student's murder could evolve by week's end.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: "There is something that is going on, but I can't tell you anything yet." Pamela J. Ames, defense attorney for Edward Hackett "The judge doesn't want me in a position to tell the press anything," Ames said Wednesday. "There is something that is going on, but I can't tell you anything yet." The 60 days began with Hackett's arraignment Nov. 14. Ames said she received more than 1,500 pages of reports, plus several hundred more pages of Hackett's medical records, including those from Utah, where he was incarcerated on kidnapping and robbery charges. Hackett was on parole from Utah when he was arrested at his parents' home in Vassalboro.
Authors: DOUG HARLOW Blethen Maine News Service

Title: Lindblom to be returned to Oregon ; Oregon had resisted the return by Maine of Dwight Lindblom, who has a history of sex crimes.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: [Dwight Lindblom], a transient with a history of sex crimes, will be returned to Oregon, where he faces a prison term for violating parole, authorities said Tuesday. Lindblom's case made news after he was arrested for harassing a woman in a Portland supermarket, and Oregon officials balked at bringing him back to serve his prison term. Cumberland County District Attorney Stephanie Anderson offered to pay for Lindblom's return even as she prosecuted him for three misdemeanor charges in Maine. Lindblom served time in prison on a rape conviction, and was on parole in a burglary case when he came to Maine in September. He violated the terms of his parole by not reporting his move from Oregon, and broke Maine law by not reporting himself as a sex offender here, authorities said.

Title: '79 murder case won't lay to rest: [All Edition]
Abstract: While [Nancy Banks] grieved for the loss of her father, the Maine academic and political communities were shocked by the violent death of one of the state's most prominent historians. As a historian of Maine and its Indian tribes, Banks was the leading researcher on the Indians' claim to state land. He wrote or edited three distinguished books of Maine history, and was completing another when he was killed. Sen. Edmund Muskie and Gov. Joseph Brennan, who were among the 400 people at the funeral, praised Banks as a kind and gentle man and an eminent scholar whose reputation extended well beyond Maine's borders. Within a month, the New Orleans police had arrested the suspected gunman, Isaac Knapper, a promising 16-year-old boxer and Olympic hopeful, along with 14-year-old Leroy Williams. They were charged with first-degree murder, although Williams later turned state's witness against his friend in exchange for a manslaughter charge. Knapper, whose long juvenile record included two armed robberies, was convicted of murder in 1979 and sentenced to life in prison with no chance of parole. Williams got seven years. Last July, however, Nancy Banks made a startling discovery that since has undermined her family's comfort and reopened some old wounds. When her husband, out of curiosity, typed the name "Isaac Knapper" into an Internet search engine, he found a Louisiana newspaper story explaining that the young man had been released from prison in 1991 when his murder conviction was overturned by the Louisiana Supreme Court.
subjectTerms: Banks, Nancy , Hakola, John , Knapper, Isaac , Williams, Leroy V

Title: Sex offender offered deal to hasten extradition: [Final Edition]
Abstract: [Stephanie Anderson] would not discuss the terms of the plea bargain, but said if the deal is accepted, [Dwight Lindblom] would face extradition to Oregon, where he would be imprisoned for violating his parole.

Title: Behind bars, it's still a time for giving: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: Flynn was the 15-year-old trigger man in the 1990 murder of Gregory Smart, husband of Pamela Smart. The notorious crime grew out of Flynn's affair with then 22-year-old Pamela, who is serving a life term without parole in New York for plotting her husband's murder with Flynn and three other teenage accomplices. Flynn, sent here from New Hampshire to serve his 28-years-to- life term, will be eligible for parole under New Hampshire law beginning in 2018. [Kevin Knight] is 13 years into a 45-year sentence. Flynn, Knight and a dozen or so other prisoners began collecting several weeks ago for the Salvation Army's Toys for Tots program. While Flynn handled the record-keeping, Knight organized the cell- to-cell solicitations - not for hard cash, which prisoners aren't allowed to have, but for small slips of paper authorizing withdrawals from their individual prison accounts.

Title: Intoxicated man violates probation: [3 Edition]
Abstract: Twaddell said he found a man later identified as Ryan Winslow, 23, of Veazie on the deck of the house. Winslow was very drunk, according to Twaddell, and said he was looking for his friend "Dell." According to Twaddell, the homeowner said Winslow had demanded entry to the house multiple times, then tried to get into the homeowner's Jeep. The homeowner said he had never met Winslow or Dell. Twaddell said Orono police Officer William King located Swaby, who allegedly said she thought the other driver had been "all set." King, at Twaddell's request, charged Swaby with leaving the scene of an accident. King said Swaby was cooperative.

Title: JUSTICE STRETCHED THIN ; Maine probation officers, overburdened with clients, work to see that homes are visited and conditions met: [Final Edition]
Abstract: with sidebar probation; "A lot of us feel if we did have smaller caseloads, we could be more effective. If people know we're going to be in their face all the time, they're more likely to meet their conditions." Scott Landry, Maine probation officer Armed and wearing bulletproof vests, Landry and fellow probation officer Mark Montminy scour Portland, knocking on doors and peering in windows as they make sure people on probation are living up to the court-ordered terms of their freedom or face more jail time. Staff photo by John Patriquin Probation officers Mark Montminy, left, and Scott Landry talk to a neighbor of a Portland probationer. The two try to make sure people on probation are living up to the court-ordered terms of their freedom or face more jail time Source: Maine Department of Corrections\ PROBATION RISE\ The number of people in Maine on probation has risen by 48 percent over the past six years while the number of probation officers has grown from 68 to 76. The average caseload for a probation officer has grown from 93 to 144 over that period. (Probationers in thousands) 1997: 6,317 2003: 9,377
subjectTerms: Landry, Scott , Montminy, Mark , Hackett, Edward

Title: Probation violators overcrowd jails ; Changes are in the works to reduce caseloads and make the system function as intended.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: sidebar probation; "The problem right now is there are way too many people on probation to take care of and people who are on probation but shouldn't be." Sen. Ethan Strimling, D-Portland, co-chair of the Legislature's Criminal Justice panel State figures show that 29 percent of the Maine's county jail population is locked up as a result of a probation violation. More than half the people placed on probation - over 5,000 - are there for misdemeanor offenses. Eliminate the use of probation for low-risk, misdemeanor offenders, except for those convicted of domestic violence or sex offenses. That change alone would reduce average probation officer caseloads to 88 and would remove about 180 inmates from the county jails statewide, the committee report said.

Title: Beehive vandal gets 7 days on probation count: [1, 2 Edition]
Abstract: [Craig Golden] was on probation for having rammed his truck into the hives, which were being used to pollinate blueberries at Merrill Blueberry Farms in Hancock, in May 2002 after he was stung by a bee. [Mary Kellett] said Thursday that Golden violated his probation a year ago by consuming alcohol. As a result of that violation, Golden agreed to undergo substance-abuse treatment, not to use any drug for which he did not have a prescription, and to use only one doctor and one pharmacy, she said. The most recent probation violation came to light when Golden tested positive for opiate use, according to the prosecutor. Also, Golden had used more than one pharmacy and doctor without telling his probation officer, she said.
subjectTerms: Golden, Craig , Kellett, Mary , Juskewitch, Steve

Title: POLICE LOG: CUMBERLAND COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT: [FINAL EDITION]
Abstract: Two officers went to the scene of a domestic dispute on Stewart Shores Road shortly after 6 p.m. A 911 phone call was cut short after the female caller's live-in boyfriend allegedly ripped the phone cord out of the wall. By the time police arrived, the man had fled to a home in Windham. Officers caught up with the 38-year-old from [Standish] in less than an hour and arrested him on charges of domestic violence assault, obstructing the report of a crime and violation of the conditions of his probation and parole. He was taken to Cumberland County Jail. Shortly after midnight, a caller reported a man and woman were fighting at the Raymond Shopping Center on Route 302. A number of people reportedly were standing around watching. The license plate number of a vehicle at the scene was given to police, who matched it to a young woman from Gray. Police went to the parking lot and talked to the woman, who said her ex-boyfriend attacked her. She showed police teeth marks on her arm where she said he had bitten her. Police later found the 24-year-old man on Wildwood Lane and arrested him on a charge of domestic violence assault. He was taken to Cumberland County Jail and was later released on bail. A Burnham Road accident did not result in any serious injuries, but after police discovered the condition of the car's driver they say it could have been much worse. The man at the wheel, a 23-year- old from Naples, reportedly was operating with a suspended license and appeared to be intoxicated when police interviewed him at about 10 p.m. He reportedly admitted to taking a number of drugs, including Vicodin, Xanax and marijuana. He also said he had been drinking Long Island iced teas. A drug recognition test was administered and the man, who was on probation, was taken to Cumberland County Jail. He was later released on bail. Some of the family members in the vehicle at the time of the accident suffered minor injuries, but all refused to press charges.

Title: Jail Alternatives: [All Edition]
Abstract: Fingers were first pointed at a parole system that allowed Mr. [Edward Hackett] to come to Maine to live with his parents after being released from a Utah prison for kidnapping a woman. A review of the reciprocal parole system, completed last week, found that it worked as it was supposed to. The problem goes much deeper than Mr. Hackett's being allowed to come to Maine. The problem is that a growing number of inmates in county jails, state prisons and federal penitentiaries suffer from mental illness. Mr. Hackett served two years of his 15-year sentence for kidnapping a woman from a Salt Lake City parking garage in 1992 at a Utah mental hospital. At his first parole hearing in 1995, he said he did not want to be paroled to the outside world, but sent instead to the state mental hospital. During his second hearing in March 2002, Mr. Hackett said that after years of being overmedicated or undermedicated, he felt his current medicine was working well. He was released on parole and came to Maine six months ago. State corrections officials, citing a confidentiality policy, are not saying whether Hackett received therapy during his time here as he had requested.

Title: State review backs handling of Hackett ; Corrections officials say Maine's supervision of the accused killer, a parolee, exceeded guidelines.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: The review concluded that the state's decision to accept [Edward J. Hackett] was made appropriately and his supervision exceeded department minimums. Even if Maine had refused to accept Hackett under a 47- state compact governing movement of parolees and probationers, he could have been released by Utah and traveled to Maine without supervision, the report said. The report also noted that Hackett's conditions of parole from Utah were only to avoid drugs and alcohol and complete counseling. Maine added additional conditions, including meeting face-to-face with a parole officer three times a month, which Hackett did. Recommends that an assessment of an offender's risk and needs be conducted before his or her acceptance by Maine. Maine conducted its own assessment once Hackett arrived, but whatever risk assessment was done by Utah corrections officials was not provided to Maine, Lord said.

Title: Utah parolee admits killing Colby student: [All Edition]
Abstract: After [Dawn Rossignol]'s body was found, police began checking probation and parole records for offenses similar to those in the case. After [Edward Hackett]'s file was reviewed, he was interviewed by police. During several interviews, he denied killing Rossignol but admitted being in the Waterville area. At the time he lived with his parents in Vassalboro. He had traveled to Waterville on Sept. 16 to get on Interstate 95 to drive to a 9 a.m. counseling session in Augusta. "At Rice Rips Road, Hackett almost hit another vehicle as Hackett was looking at the Rice Rip Road side of the road," the affidavit states. A DNA sample obtained from Hackett police say matches DNA samples taken from the driver's side interior door handle of Rossignol's car. Because Hackett went public with his confession of murdering Rossignol this week, Deputy District Attorney William Stokes withdrew his motion Thursday to impound court documents. Defense Attorney Pamela Ames had no objection. She said after the hearing that Hackett had given the interview against her advice.
Authors: SHARON KILEY MACK;OF THE NEWS STAFF
subjectTerms: Rossignol, Dawn , Hackett, Edward , Ames, Pamela

Title: AFFIDAVITS: DNA IN CAR LINKED HACKETT TO KILLING: [FINAL EDITION]
Abstract: with two sidebars Hackett verifed; DEVELOPMENTS IN CASE Sept. 16 Colby College senior Dawn M. Rossignol is abducted from a parking lot on the Waterville campus after leaving her dorm around 7:20 a.m. Rossignol was on her way to a 9 a.m. doctor's appointment in Bangor. Her mother, Charleen, reports her daughter missing to police after she fails to show up for the appointment. Sept. 17 Rossignol's body is discovered less than a mile from the college, about 300 yards from her 1993 Mercury Sable, which is found parked in Oakland on an access road to a hydropower facility on Messalonskee Stream. Sept. 18 Rossignol's death is ruled a homicide. About 100 police, game wardens and cadets from the Maine Criminal Justice Academy search the area for clues. Sept. 22 Hundreds gather at St. Agatha Catholic Church for Rossignol's funeral. The 21-year-old was born in St. Agatha and grew up in Medway. Sept. 23 Maine State Police confirm that they are holding a suspect in the murder. Edward J. Hackett, 47, is being held on a parole violation from Utah and is being questioned in connection with Rossignol's death. Sept. 25 The state files kidnapping and murder charges against Hackett. Oct. 2 Hackett makes his first appearance at Waterville District Court. Judge John Nivison orders Hackett to undergo psychological evaluations to determine his mental competency at the time of the murder. The judge also orders Hackett held without bail and sets Nov. 18 for a probable cause hearing. Oct. 15 Hackett confesses to murdering Rossignol in an interview with the Portland Press Herald/Maine Sunday Telegram at the Kennebec County Jail. Oct. 16 A judge unseals police affidavits detailing evidence in the case after state prosecutors drop objections to making the information public. The Press Herald/Telegram had challenged the decision to impound the documents. - Compiled by staff researcher Julia McCue
subjectTerms: Rossignol, Dawn M , Hackett, Edward J

Title: Utah: Hackett deflecting the blame ; Officials call Edward Hackett's criticism of the state for granting him parole `pathetic.': [Final Edition]
Abstract: Officials in Utah expressed disgust Wednesday at [Edward Hackett]'s contention that their state was somehow to blame for the killing of Dawn Rossignol. John Green, administrative coordinator for the Utah Board of Pardons and Parole, said that Hackett is merely trying to deflect blame. Mike Sibbett, chairman of the Utah Board of Pardons and Parole, said he was offended by Hackett's contention.

Title: Maine corrections agency reviews handling of case ; The supervision of all parolees from out of state also is being studied.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: At the direction of Gov. John Baldacci, Maine corrections officials are reviewing the handling of accused killer Edward J. Hackett's parole as well as the supervision of other out-of-state parolees. Hackett, who had a history of attacking women, was released from a Utah prison in March and went to live with his parents in Vassalboro, where he was under the supervision of the Maine Department of Corrections. Last month, he was charged with killing a Colby College senior. The extent of his supervision in Maine is not clear. [Martin Magnusson]'s review of the Hackett case and the state's handling of other parolees from out of state remains under way.

Title: Hackett drifted in and out of jail, prison ; In the decades before a Colby student's slaying, the suspect committed crime after crime across the country.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: with sidebar Hackett; LONG CRIMINAL RECORD Edward J. Hackett, who is facing a murder charge in the slaying of Colby College senior Dawn Rossignol, has a criminal record dating back more than 30 years: June 28, 1956: Edward Hackett is born. Aug. 19, 1972: Connecticut. Charged with disorderly conduct. June 27, 1973: Connecticut. Charged with larceny. Sept. 22, 1973: Arrested on a Massachusetts kidnapping charge and for being a fugitive from justice. Transferred to Massachusetts. Sentenced to two years in prison. May 1976: Massachusetts. Faces six counts of burglary and is sentenced to six months in jail. Feb. 20, 1977: Connecticut. Arrested on kidnapping charges, which are reduced to unlawful restraint. Sentenced to nine months in jail. Oct. 23, 1977: South Carolina. Arrested on charge of disorderly conduct. Convicted. Aug. 24, 1979: Utah. Arrested on charges of automobile theft. Pleads guilty to attempted automobile theft. Sentenced to one to five years. September 1979: Utah. Escapes. Nov. 21, 1980: Utah. Returned. Convicted of felony escape, sentenced to zero to five years concurrent with theft charge. May 22, 1981: Utah. Escapes. Captured the same day. March 9, 1982: Utah. Paroled. Jan. 10, 1983: Texas. Arrested for auto theft. Sentenced to three years probation. Jan. 11, 1984: South Carolina. Fraudulent check charges. Convicted. April 6, 1984: South Carolina. Fraudulent check charge. Convicted Nov. 12, 1984. Oct. 16, 1984: Utah. Returned to prison, charged with escape. Also charged with theft by deception, but not prosecuted. Feb. 5, 1985: California. Arrested on fugitive from parole charges. May 21, 1985: California. Charged with multiple burglaries, sentenced to three years in prison. Serves one year and is transferred to Utah. Jan. 16, 1986: Utah. Convicted of escape. March 17, 1986: Utah. Committed to Utah State Prison. Oct. 13, 1987: Utah. Paroled. Eventually absconds. Aug. 19, 1988: Massachusetts. Sentenced to three years in prison for burglary, released in 1991. March 5, 1992: Utah. Charged with aggravated kidnapping, aggravated sexual assault and aggravated robbery. Eventually pleads guilty to kidnapping and robbery. He spends just less than two years at the Utah state mental hospital for evaluation before beginning his prison term. April 14, 1994: Utah. Arrives at Utah State Prison. March 2003: Utah. Paroled to Maine. Sept. 16, 2003: Waterville. Dawn Rossignol, a 21-year-old Colby College student, is reported missing. Sept. 17, 2003: Oakland. Rossignol's body is found in a stream, about 300 yards from her car. Sept. 25, 2003: Hackett is charged with kidnapping and murdering Rossignol. Sources: Connecticut Department of Public Safety, Maine State Police, South Carolina Law Enforcement Division records, Utah Department of Corrections, Massachusetts Department of Corrections

Title: PAROLE SUPERVISION REPORT DUE ; Some aspects of Hackett's handling to be released: [Final Edition]
Abstract: [Edward J. Hackett] was identified as a possible suspect in [Dawn Rossignol]'s death after the corrections department searched its records for anyone living in the area who was recently released on probation or parole after committing similar crimes. Last year, during Hackett's Utah parole hearing, he said he needed a structured parole program, including mental health therapy to avoid committing new crimes. But state officials so far have refused to detail the extent to which Hackett was involved in such a program. Some broad parole conditions were established by Utah. But Hackett's specific requirements were set by his parole officer in Maine after a risk assessment.
subjectTerms: Hackett, Edward J , Rossignol, Dawn , Blanchette, Patricia

Title: Suspect sought structured parole ; 'I don't want any way to screw up no more,' Dawn Rossignol's accused slayer told a Utah parole board.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Today, Hackett, 47, stands charged with kidnapping and killing 21- year-old Colby College senior Dawn Rossignol of Medway. Rossignol was abducted from a parking lot on the Waterville campus on Sept. 16. Her body was found the next day in nearby Oakland. Hackett is being held without bail at the Kennebec County Jail pending a probable causing hearing on Nov. 18. The Maine Department of Corrections will not describe what kind of supervision or counseling it provided for Hackett after officials accepted his transfer from Utah. The Portland Press Herald/Maine Sunday Telegram has filed a request for Hackett's supervision records under the state's Right-to-Know law. State Sen. Ethan Strimling, chairman of the Legislature's Criminal Justice Committee, said he has concerns about the adequacy of Hackett's supervision while in Maine. He said he has not seen Hackett's risk assessment, or the other material provided by Utah authorities when Hackett was being transferred to Maine.
subjectTerms: Hackett, Edward J , Rossignol, Dawn , Garner, Curtis , Strimling, Ethan

Title: Suspect appears in court No plea entered in slaying: [All Edition]
Abstract: State police were alerted to Hackett as a possible suspect after the Department of Corrections reviewed its list of parolees. Hackett came to Maine from Utah under a 50-state compact that allows parolees and probationers to move from state to state when they are released from prison. The compact allows Maine or any other state to accept or reject responsibility for supervising someone like Hackett. The security measures at the courthouse and the bulletproof vest worn by Hackett were prompted because "of inappropriate comments that had not risen to the level of threats," [Pamela Ames, Hackett] said. She said she will be enlisting Steven Chandler of Waterville as co-counsel in the case. "The random abduction and murder of a Colby College senior and the arrest of a career criminal on parole in connection with her death is a matter of tremendous public interest," the memorandum states. "The case raises questions about whether authorities made mistakes in supervising Hackett's parole. This goes to the heart of public confidence in Maine's public safety system. Access to court records is also vital to the public's confidence ... High profile cases, such as this one, set the standard by which the system is judged."
Authors: SHARON KILEY MACK;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: TESTS ORDERED FOR MURDER SUSPECT ; Edward J. Hackett tells the judge he understands the charges, but he'll still undergo psychological evaluations.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: [Edward J. Hackett], the Utah parolee accused of kidnapping and murdering a Colby College student, was ordered Thursday to undergo psychological evaluations. Waterville District Court Judge John Nivison called for an exam by the state forensic service and an independent review by an outside evaluator. The results will be used to determine Hackett's mental competency now, and at the time he allegedly killed 21-year-old Dawn Rossignol of Medway. Hackett, who moved to Maine in March, spent nine years in Utah prisons and mental institutions after he was arrested for abducting a woman at knifepoint in 1992. At the time of Rossignol's disappearance, Hackett was on parole from Utah and under the supervision of the Maine Department of Corrections. Photo by David Leaming Blethen Maine Newspapers Edward J. Hackett, 47, the Utah parolee charged with killing Colby College student Dawn Rossignol, sits quietly in court Thursday next to his attorney, [Pamela Ames]. Hackett was not asked to enter a plea, and the judge scheduled a probable cause hearing for Nov. 18. Photo by David Leaming, Blethen Maine Newspapers Defendant in Colby slaying appears in court Edward J. Hackett wears a bulletproof vest Thursday as he is escorted into Waterville District Court. His lawyer, Pamela Ames, said she asked for the vest because of concerns for her client's safety after hearing "inappropriate comments" from people who were upset that she took the case.

Title: 330 parolees have moved to Maine Multistate compact in place: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Edward Hackett] was allowed to move to Maine under an interstate compact governing community corrections that was established in 1930. The compact allows released prisoners still under supervision to move to other states to live and work. Under the compact, a paroled prisoner's adherence to parole conditions would be monitored by Maine corrections officials, even though Maine no longer offers parole to its own prisoners. Parole offers prisoners early release from their sentences for the promise of future good behavior. Maine uses probation, a set of conditions a former prisoner must follow upon completion of a sentence. In addition to parole or probation conditions imposed by the "sending" state, such as no use of alcohol or a curfew, Maine officials have the right to impose additional conditions on the offender, Lord said. She said, however, the department is not legally allowed to say whether they had imposed additional conditions on Hackett.

Title: Arrest made in Colby killing Suspect on parole at home of parents in Vassalboro: [All Edition]
Abstract: Edward J. Hackett, 47, convicted of a similar crime in Utah in 1992 and released on parole for that crime in March, is in custody at Kennebec County Jail without bail and is expected to be charged with murder within the next few days, said Maine State Police Lt. Timothy Doyle, the commander of the investigation that began last Wednesday with the discovery of Rossignol's body. In March 1992, Hackett kidnapped a 24-year-old woman from a downtown parking terrace. He robbed the woman, forced her into her car and commanded her to drive him to Ogden, about 40 minutes away. On the way, he had her stop the car and allegedly tried to rape her, but the assault was interrupted by a Salt Lake City police officer who fought with Hackett for several minutes, according to newspaper reports. Her mother reported Rossignol missing when she failed to show up in Bangor for a doctor's appointment. Rossignol's car was spotted the next morning on a dirt road leading down to the Rice Rips Hydro Plant about a mile from campus. Her body was found about 300 feet from the car near Messalonskee Stream.

Title: Police: Parolee killed Colby College senior ; Edward J. Hackett, released from a Utah prison in March, is being held in the death of Dawn Rossignol: [Final Edition]
Abstract: The man who police say killed a Colby College senior came to Maine six months ago on parole from a Utah prison after serving nine years for a hauntingly similar crime there. Edward J. Hackett, 47, is being held in maximum security at the Kennebec County Jail, charged with a parole violation. Authorities expect the state Attorney General's Office to bring formal charges later this week accusing Hackett of the abduction and murder of Dawn Rossignol, a 21- year-old from Medway who was reported missing after leaving her dormitory the morning of Sept. 16. Police tracked down Hackett on Monday when the state Department of Corrections checked its database of convicts with similar criminal backgrounds who lived in the area. Hackett lived with his parents, a short drive away in Vassalboro, after being released in March from the Utah state prison system, where he had been held since 1994. Staff photo by Doug Jones Colby College President William Adams answers questions concerning campus security Tuesday after the arrest of a suspect in the abduction and slaying of Colby senior Dawn Rossignol last week. Dawn Rossignol Edward J. Hackett was arrested in Utah in 1992 and charged with abducting a 24-year-old woman at knifepoint from a parking lot. Staff photo by Doug Jones Students and others crowd the Harold Alfond Athletic Complex at Colby College, where state police announced Edward J. Hackett's arrest.
Authors: DAVID HENCH Staff Writer Staff Writer Joshua Weinstein contributed to this report.
subjectTerms: Doyle, Timothy , Ford, Jack , Hackett, Dawn Rossignol Edward J

Title: Police question Vassalboro man: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Edward J. Hackett] returned to Maine last March when he was released on parole from a Utah prison where he had served several years after a 1994 conviction for kidnapping and robbery. According to Jack Ford of the Utah Department of Corrections, Hackett's first conviction there was in 1979 for theft. Hackett was in and out of the Utah State Prison in Draper, Utah, during the 1980s and escaped two or three times, Ford said.

Title: Woman sentenced to 50 years for murder Child-care provider was stabbed in 2001: [All Edition]
Abstract: Family members and friends of the murder victim, Tara Bell, 27, wept and stared at [Laura Kirk] as she left the room. Bell's mother, Glenda Roy, cried as she hugged Tammy Keiser, one of her daughter's friends and child-care customers. As Roy wept, she cried, "Not fair, not fair!" of Kirk's 50-year sentence. The state had urged a life sentence. [Peter S. Kelley] cited several mitigating factors, including Kirk's feelings of remorse, as a rationale for the lesser sentence. Kelley stated Kirk had no criminal record. He also said Kirk was suicidal, that she had lost her job and that her mental status was declining near the time of the murder. Kirk will be transferred to the Women's Correctional Center in Windham. She will not be eligible for parole, which was abolished in Maine in 1975, but she will be eligible for "good time" easing of the sentence.
subjectTerms: Kirk, Laura , Bell, Tara , Roy, Glenda , Stokes, William , Kelley, Peter S

Title: Calais man sentenced to prison Judge denies Strikefoot probation, gives 77-year-old jail time: [All Edition]
Abstract: The incident occurred Nov. 9, and it took two jury trials to reach a guilty verdict. The first jury deadlocked. The second jury last week found [Vernald Strikefoot] guilty of attempted gross sexual assault. [Carletta Bassano] said that in the 1980s Strikefoot had been convicted of violation of privacy law and harassment. He was placed on probation, which he later violated. "The state does not see him as a candidate for probation," she said. After [Ellen Gorman] sentenced him, Strikefoot again asked for leniency. "I am 77 years old. I will be in my 80s. My wife will be dead, friends and family will be dead, so I will have nothing to come back to," he said.

Title: Man returned to prison for probation violations: [1, 2 Edition]
Abstract: On Wednesday, [Kenneth Lyons] was sent back to prison for a variety of reasons. He left the state and traveled to Tennessee and Massachusetts without his probation officer's permission, admitted to consuming alcohol and marijuana, failed to undergo substance abuse counseling, and failed to repay the $450 he stole from his friend, court documents indicate.

Title: More than probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: The individual who stole the fish and burned it to death (BDN, July 11) sounds like a person who needs much more than probation and has a much larger problem than liking to steal. Unfortunately, 56 days in jail didn't help reform him, since he committed this disgusting crime within two hours of his release.

Title: Parole eyed to ease crowded prisons 17-member commission to review sentencing, reports on released inmates: [All Edition]
Abstract: As the state's prison population swells to its current 2,000 inmates - who, on average, each cost the state $33,885 annually - the idea of freeing cell space by releasing even small numbers of deserving prisoners could become a viable option. At least, that's what Jeffrey L. Libby hopes. A convicted murderer with more than 20 years left on his sentence, the Windham inmate recently wrote the Bangor Daily News explaining why parole is an idea whose time has returned. "We can't just keep adding more and more prisoners," she said. "I'm a proponent of prison reform, and parole is one of the things we need to look at. I think that when we got rid of parole, we threw the baby out with the bath water. Twenty states still have parole. If there were problems with the parole board, then they should have just done something about the parole board. That was the '70s. That was then, this is now." Rather than weighing early supervised release, Lord said the state should explore alternatives to incarceration. Should discussions proceed to actual legislative recommendations for parole, Lord said, the corrections department would want to be involved in determining prisoner eligibility.
Authors: Higgins, A J;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: Dover-Foxcroft police moving in to new station: [1, 3 Edition]
Abstract: "They [the inmates] have saved taxpayers well over $100,000," [Dennis Dyer] said. "I can't say enough about that." The inmates, under the watchful eyes of Corrections Officer John Roberts, have performed a variety of tasks, from replacing walls, floors and ceilings, to installing doors and windows. Dyer also credited his department, Selectman Elwood Ederly, resident Roger Davis, and John Roberts and his family for donating numerous hours doing odd jobs, from refinishing floors to cleaning the facility to save money. "It was a community effort," he explained. The $4,200-a-year rent from Probation and Parole and the rent from the apartment will help offset maintenance costs, according to Dyer. The department also will no longer have to pay for storage of its evidence.

Title: Man goes back to jail for burning tropical fish Alleged theft from pet store violates probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Jhon Hallett]'s probation was partially revoked Thursday by Hancock County Superior Court Justice Andrew Mead. Mead ordered Hallett's probation revoked for five days, but gave the Ellsworth man credit for the five days he served in jail after the fish-burning incident. Within a few minutes, store employees called police, who tracked the trio to a nearby fast-food restaurant. After reviewing a videotape from a store security camera, which recorded Hallett and the boy going to the fish tank where the fish had been kept, police arrested Hallett for violating his probation. [Mary Kellett] said the state agreed to drop criminal charges against Hallett in exchange for his probation being revoked. She said Hallett has been cooperative with the terms of his probation since the incident.

Title: Court upholds probation revocation decision: [All Edition]
Abstract: A majority of the justices agreed that because neither [Harold Shepley] nor his probation officer applied to terminate his probation, it was still in effect when he was arrested a year ago. Justices Howard H. Dana Jr. and Donald G. Alexander dissented, stating that once the court learned Shepley had completed the conditions of his probation, the probation should have been terminated retroactively to the date the conditions were met. He finished the batterers intervention program Feb. 19, 2002, but did not file a motion with the court to terminate his probation. Shepley was arrested April 27, 2002, and charged with criminal mischief. Two days later, Shepley's probation officer filed a motion to revoke his probation.

Title: 4-wheeler at center of theft charge: [3 Edition]
Abstract: Officer John Knapp said he was on patrol just before 2 a.m. when he saw a car moving fast on Chamberlain Street. Knapp caught up with the car on Eastern Avenue heading toward Holden. Knapp said the driver, Benjamin Moorside, 22, was on probation. Because Moorside allegedly had been drinking, the Department of Probation and Parole had Knapp hold him for violation of his probation.

Title: Sex offender kept mum about ice cream job ; An ice cream truck driver arrested near a Portland school didn't tell his probation officer where he was working.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: [Robert Andre Bouthot], 34, is on probation as a result of a 1999 conviction for unlawful sexual contact with a 13-year-old girl. Bouthot served six months in jail, and a condition of his probation was that he have no unsupervised contact with children under 16. He also is a registered sex offender in Maine, classified as a "sexually violent predator." On Sunday afternoon, [Sue Weichman], who works primarily with sex offenders in York County, received a call from South Portland police officer Thomas Simonds. Simonds was alarmed because he had been checking the license plates of cars near the rail yard on Rigby Road where ice cream trucks are kept overnight, and Bouthot's name appeared. [Michael Roach], who supervises Weichman and 21 other probation officers, defended his department's handling of Bouthot and pointed out that an arrest was made just two hours after Weichman learned that Bouthot was driving the ice cream truck.

Title: Dover-Foxcroft OKs probation, parole move: [3 Edition]
Abstract: The only opposition aired Thursday against the proposal was from Robert Berta, who lives on River Street behind the station. "I just think it's a bad mix," Berta said, referring to the probation office and the Thompson Free Library located next door. Dan Dixon, probation and parole officer, assured the audience there has been no trouble involving probationers at his office. He said 43 adults on probation currently report to him about twice a month. The crimes that the individuals have been convicted of vary, but include three sex offenders. The juvenile office also will be located at the site. Those on probation are being monitored in the community, Dixon said, and the police would provide an extra set of eyes for the probation office.

Title: 2 men arrested after break-in complaint: [3 Edition]
Abstract: A man came down the stairs with bloody hands, [James Buckley] said. [John Robinson] recognized him as Daniel Leduc, 22, of Bangor. Buckley and [Bob Bishop] left Leduc with Robinson and [Christopher Blanchard]. Bishop said that while he was talking to Probation and Parole about Leduc's case, Leduc approached him insisting to speak to the probation officer. Bishop held Leduc away by placing his hand on Leduc's chest at which point Leduc tried to bite Bishop and spat on him. Leduc then started walking away, Bishop said. Buckley said he stopped Leduc, who kicked him in the inner thigh and tried to spit on him as well. Buckley said he pinned Leduc to the seat of the cruiser with his head turned away so he couldn't spit at him.

Title: Dover-Foxcroft station may house other departments: [3 Edition]
Abstract: The probation and parole department serving Piscataquis County hopes to relocate to the new Dover-Foxcroft police station on East Main Street once that facility is open in June. In order to do so, the local planning board will conduct a site plan review on the proposed relocation at 6:30 p.m. April 3. Dover-Foxcroft Police Chief Dennis Dyer said Friday that he expects his department will move to the new facility by late May or early June. He believes adding the probation and parole department to the building could generate as much as $4,300 a year in rent. Robert Berta, who lives across the road from the new station, and his attorney, Ed Bearor of Bangor, have filed an appeal in Piscataquis County Superior Court against the project. Berta and Bearor claim the town did not follow its own ordinance when the site plan was approved for the police station.

Title: Consider parole: [All Edition]
Abstract: The new prison is overcrowded and was so shortly after it opened.

Title: Cooper sentenced to 1-year probation Former Maine football player had prior record: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Margaret Kravchuk], who pointed out that [Stephen Cooper Sr.] had been convicted in the past of criminal mischief and disorderly conduct, also ordered Cooper to be drug-tested within the next 15 days and to be tested at least twice more over the next year. [Terrence Harrigan] said Cooper had been a role model on and off the field, was active in the community and had taken steps to "right his wrong." He offered several letters of support for Cooper. [Daniel Perry] said in dealing with Cooper and Harrigan, he felt Cooper was sincerely remorseful for his actions.

Title: Cooper given probation ; Ex-UMaine football player Stephen Cooper is eager to start community service, his lawyer says.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: "That's what we hoped for," said Terence Harrigan, [Stephen Cooper]'s Bangor attorney. "Stephen came forward immediately and was very cooperative. He basically did everything that someone should do in that situation. Court records indicate that the driver consented to a search of his car. During that search, three bags containing 1,262 pills were found in a duffel bag behind Cooper's seat. Cooper admitted that the pills were his and that they were steroids. Harrigan said the incident has dropped Cooper's stock among NFL teams. Cooper, a devastating tackler, was the defensive leader on a Maine team that made it to the Division I-AA quarterfinals for a second straight year.

Title: Richmond man gets eight years for molesting sisters ; Ronald Pinkham, who also gets 16 years' probation, pleads guilty and apologizes to the victims' family.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: A Richmond man was sentenced to eight years in prison and 16 years' probation Friday for sexually assaulting three young sisters. Ronald "Riley" Pinkham, 59, sobbed during his sentencing in Sagadahoc County Superior Court in Bath as he apologized in front of a courtroom full of members of his own family and the victims' family. The father of the girls said he could only pray his daughters will be able to go on with their lives. "Faith is extremely important to us, and Mr. [Ronald Pinkham] blasted our faith by molesting our daughters," he said. "He won (the girls') trust by talking to them about God. My children know that eternal salvation is everything. And so does Mr. Pinkham. And he used that against them. He not only raped their bodies, but their faith as well." Pinkham, a slight man who walks with a cane, tearfully addressed the court. "I just ask that there be no hate," Pinkham said. "I hurt people. And I'm sorry."
Authors: KEITH EDWARDS Blethen Maine News Service

Title: MAN WHO IMPORTED KHAT GETS PROBATION ; A Somali from Portland receives the lightest sentence possible in a case of clashing cultures and strict drug laws.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: In October, in the first khat-related trial in Maine, a federal jury found [Abdigani Hussein] guilty of possessing and intending to distribute an illegal drug. The trial, closely watched by members of Maine's refugee community, was one of a growing number of similar cases reaching courts around the country as the cultures of new immigrants clash with stringent American drug laws. Hussein was one of the first people nationwide to be convicted in such a trial. [D. Brock Hornby] said the small quantity of illegal chemicals found in the khat, along with Hussein's behavior, led him to impose the minimum sentence possible - probation for one year. Hornby even granted permission for Hussein to travel to certain cities to buy supplies for a Somali grocery store he has helped start in Portland. The charge carried a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. Hussein clearly wants to avoid deportation, and not only because of the hardships of returning to Somalia. As he stood before Hornby in U.S. District Court, Hussein's wife was in early labor with her first child at Maine Medical Center. Hussein, who chose to go on with the sentencing Thursday rather than postpone it, quickly left for the hospital after receiving his sentence.

Title: Probation for courts?: [All Edition]
Abstract: A clipping from the Jan. 17 Bangor Daily News stated that a convicted murderer and child...

Title: Ex-Canaan firefighter jailed for probation violation Judge warns town to resolve internal issues: [3 Edition]
Abstract: SKOWHEGAN - Somerset County Superior Court Justice Nancy Mills sent former Canaan firefighter Pat Miner to jail for 20 days Wednesday for attending a Canaan fire scene which violated the terms of his probation, but she did not pass up the opportunity to warn about 50 Canaan residents and town officials in the courtroom that they had better start getting along. Miner is one of two former Canaan firefighters whose terms of probation banned them from Canaan fire scenes as part of an escalating atmosphere of discontent over the past several years. The town has become divided and hostile over which is the real Canaan Fire Department: the municipal department or the Canaan Firefighters' Association. Fights have erupted at selectmen's meetings and assaults have happened at fire scenes. More than a dozen firefighters left or were asked to leave the department. The parade of witnesses illustrated how deep the division in Canaan is with former firefighters testifying that Canaan firefighters had reversed the hoses on a pumper truck, hooking the intake hose to a discharge valve. They testified that Canaan firefighters were shooting water in the wrong direction to protect the home. They testified that a hose laid to the back of the house split when it was filled.
Authors: SHARON KILEY MACK;OF THE NEWS STAFF
subjectTerms: Mills, Nancy , Miner, Pat , Murphy, Harry , Robinson, Michael

Title: State corrections chief renominated: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Magnusson], 54, presided over an unprecedented period of transformation in the state corrections system that included the construction of a new Maine State Prison, a self-contained incarceration center for female prisoners and two new juvenile detention centers with completely revamped rehabilitation programs. In a brief interview Monday, Magnusson said addressing the challenge posed by those ongoing state revenue deficits would be his first priority as [John E. Baldacci]'s corrections commissioner. Currently, the state Department of Corrections operates on an annual budget of about $126 million. Scaling back state spending without diminishing security measures or vital program development will force Magnusson to scrutinize a system that continues to experience a sharp increase in the number of adult prisoners. Magnusson has been a state probation and parole officer, and was also a former state director of juvenile services. From 1982 to 1995, he served as the warden of the Maine State Prison, the Maine Correctional Institute and the Bolduc Correctional Facility.
Authors: Higgins, A J;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: PUBLIC INFORMATION: [ALL EDITION]
Abstract: Certainly, there are some serious issues with the information act in Maine. Most importantly is that it can be entirely circumvented through meetings and phone calls that are never announced but that can be where the real decisions are made. And lawmakers seem to take particular glee in creating exemptions to the act. There are more than 100 statutes blocking public access now covering ballots after elections, workers' comp board minutes, child-support payment records, parole board recommendations sent to the governor and the location of ginseng plantings. Members of the public should recognize that the ease with which legislators hide documents eventually will affect them and, in any event, makes waste, fraud and abuse that much easier to perpetrate.

Title: COOPER SAYS STEROIDS WERE FOR NFL TRYOUT ; The UMaine linebacker pleads guilty, agreeing to a deal that may include a fine and probation.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: University of Maine All-America linebacker Stephen Cooper pleaded guilty Thursday in federal court to steroid possession. He acknowledged, in a statement released by his lawyer, that he had planned to use the drugs to prepare for a National Football League tryout. Cooper pleaded guilty to the misdemeanor charge of possessing a Schedule III controlled substance. After a 16-minute court appearance, U.S. Magistrate Margaret J. Kravchuk released Cooper on his own recognizance. A sentencing report will be delivered within 45 days. Cooper has been tested five times by the NCAA for illegal drugs and each test has been negative. He will not return to Maine and plans to move back to Massachusetts to prepare for the NFL draft. The court agreed to the move as long as Cooper returns for sentencing. Cooper was a passenger in a sport utility vehicle of former teammate Patrick Kenney when a Maine state trooper stopped Kenney for speeding on Interstate 95 in Hampden on Nov. 1. Kenney gave the trooper consent to search the vehicle, and a bag with more than 1,000 pills was found in the back seat. At that time, Cooper told the trooper the pills were steroids and they belonged to him.

Title: Police Log ; Standish, Naples, Raymond and Gray are covered by the Cumberland County Sheriff's Office.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Another motorist was involuntarily stopped on Bonny Eagle Road just before 4 a.m. The 22-year-old man from [Gray] was wanted on a warrant for failing to appear in court for a prior offense. He was taken to Cumberland County Jail. Rifle fire in the King's Grant Road neighborhood turned into a dangerous pursuit onto thin ice. Three callers reported hearing shots just after 3 a.m. Numerous officers rushed to the area and gave chase to a 39-year-old man, who took off in his car. He soon pulled into a driveway and took off on foot, with two officers in pursuit. When they caught up to him, he had ventured onto the inch- thick ice of Raymond Pond. Scooting across the cracking ice, the officers tried to subdue the man with pepper spray. They eventually wrestled him to shore after falling through the ice and all three were treated for exposure to the cold water. The local resident was charged with operating under the influence, reckless conduct with a firearm, carrying a concealed weapon, failure to stop for an officer and failing to submit to an arrest. Eight officers were involved in the chase. The man was later released on $500 bail. Drinking was forbidden in the terms of a Windham man's parole, but that didn't stop him from reportedly becoming intoxicated. His probation officer was notified of the 20-year-old's presence at the Route 100 Cumberland Farms at 12:40 a.m. An officer arrested the man.

Title: Man on probation back in jail Positive cocaine test violates sentencing conditions in fatal crash: [All Edition]
Abstract: [MacArthur] was convicted of four counts of manslaughter and sentenced to 15 years in prison, with all but nine years suspended and six years' probation. With time off for good behavior under previous Maine law, MacArthur served a little more than five years and was released in January 2001. In August and September of this year, MacArthur tested positive for cocaine in two tests conducted by his probation officer. During his initial sentencing hearing on Oct. 3, his attorney, Jeffrey Toothaker, said MacArthur's use of the drug was directly related to the approach of the Oct. 30 anniversary of the crash. "His downfall is substance abuse," said Toothaker, recommending that MacArthur be sentenced to time served and that a condition of his probation be substance abuse counseling and counseling in grief and loss.
Authors: Clancy, Mary Anne;OF THE NEWS STAFF
subjectTerms: Mills, Nancy , Toothaker, Jeffrey , Cavanaugh, Paul

Title: BAIL HEARING CANCELED IN CITY STABBING: [FINAL EDITION]
Abstract: Attorney Howard O'Brien said he has asked for an exam that would determine if John Mandarelli, 29, is mentally competent to stand trial and whether he knew the difference between right and wrong Sunday, when witnesses said he plunged an 8-inch knife into the chest of Jeffrey Rainey, 32, who was trying to prevent Mandarelli from stealing a pair of pants from Olympia Sports in Portland. The first-stage evaluation, which would determine Mandarelli's present level of competence, was ordered by District Court Judge Keith Powers after Mandarelli made an initial court appearance Monday. During the hearing, Mandarelli made comments that indicated he did not fully appreciate the serious charges against him. He said at one point he needed to be released on bail so he could keep his job and an apartment. He has been charged with murder and, if convicted, faces life in prison without parole. James Hewes, Mandarelli's lawyer in the 2000 cases, said the stabbing charge seemed out of character for the man he represented. "John's not that kind of guy," Hewes said. "He didn't seem to be that dangerous."
subjectTerms: O Brien, Howard , Mandarelli, John , Soucy, Derek

Title: Banned man violates probation Ex-Pittsfield resident returns, reportedly threatens estranged wife: [2 Edition]
Abstract: There were no other employees at the agricultural facility where [Kelly Calcia] was working Sunday, said Pittsfield police Sgt. Timothy Roussin. About midafternoon, the woman called her stepfather in Florida and told him of the assault. The stepfather called the Maine State Police, who notified Pittsfield officers. In August, Calcia fled his Pittsfield home after firing a gun when his brother-in-law tried to stop a domestic dispute between Calcia and his wife. No one was injured. While Calcia was jailed, Kelly Calcia gave Pittsfield police permission to dispose of all the farm animals located at the couple's Powers Road home, and they were sold at auction. The house has been repossessed, and the couple's children have been placed in state custody.
Authors: SHARON KILEY MACK;OF THE NEWS STAFF
subjectTerms: Calcia, Marc , Calcia, Kelly , Fowle, Evert

Title: Heath changes plea to guilty in hammer slaying of cabdriver: [All Edition]
Abstract: Heath's court-appointed attorney, Walter "Woody" Hanstein of Farmington said after the proceeding that he would ask the judge to sentence Heath to eight or 10 years less than the 42 recommended by [William Stokes] with a long period of probation. Sentencing was set for Friday, Nov. 15, in Bangor. Stokes said Heath was brought from Thomaston to Bangor that day to face minor theft charges in 3rd District Court. The judge sentenced him to time served. Heath was released and told to report to a parole officer in Portland on Oct. 15, 2001. [Donna Leen] was dispatched to pick Heath up at the MDOT trailer between 12:30 and 1 p.m., Stokes said. Heath stopped at a house on Hemlock Point Road between 1:30 and 1:45 p.m. and told the residents he was looking for his grandmother's house. According to Stokes, witnesses saw him get into a white cab driven by a woman.

Title: Emotion fills air in drug use case Man on probation caused '94 fatalities: [All Edition]
Abstract: Justice Nancy Mills said she wanted more time to review a pre- sentencing report for 30-year-old Ellis "Jamie" MacArthur and the letters of support his defense attorney said would show MacArthur's progress since he was released from prison in January 2001. "Patty, I'm so sorry, I'm just so sorry," MacArthur said to Patty Meta, [Ronald Armstrong]'s widow and mother of the three children killed in the accident. MacArthur has done very well on probation in every other aspect of his life, [Jeffrey Toothaker] said. He's married, has two stepchildren, and supports both his family and his parents. Toothaker said MacArthur's wife reports he becomes very upset at this time every year.

Title: MAN GETS FIVE YEARS IN PRISON FOR RAPE ; John Sawyer, 25, of Portland, who assaulted a former girlfriend, also faces strict probation conditions.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: For the rest of his life, Sawyer will have to register with a local law enforcement agency as a violent sexual predator. While on probation, he will have to participate in sex offender treatment and batterers' intervention programs. He cannot use or possess alcohol, drugs or dangerous weapons, and must submit to random searches and testing. Sawyer also waived his right to appeal his rape conviction. Sawyer was living in the Oxford Street Shelter last winter when he met the victim, who had volunteered to drive him and three other men to Sunday services at her church. Sawyer and the victim began dating, but she felt pressured by him to have sex. The threatening charge also involved a former girlfriend. Carol Scott said she and Sawyer were having an argument over money last year. She said Sawyer pointed a gun at her and yelled, "Let's end it all," and then told her he would shoot at police if she called them.

Title: Cosgrove awaits word on wideouts Probation ends as Husson is now full-fledged NCAA Div. III school: [1 Edition]
Abstract: It was reported incorrectly in a headline on a College Report story on Page C1 in Friday's editions that Husson College had been on NCAA probation. Husson, which has been awarded active membership in the NCAA, had been a provisional member of the organization for the previous four years. Beginning this academic year, Husson will be eligible to participate in NCAA Championships. Membership also enables [Husson] to have a vote at the annual NCAA Convention. "I am extremely excited for Husson because this opens up opportunities for our students and the school which we didn't have in a single affiliation," said Husson athletic director Pam Hennessey.

Title: Bangor robber sentenced to 4 years, no probation: [4 Edition]
Abstract: Nathan L. Tenney, whose legal name is Nathan L. Miller, was sentenced to four years in prison for Class A robbery. Justice Jeffrey Hjelm rejected the Penobscot County District Attorney's recommendation that Tenney be sentenced to four years with all but one suspended and three years' probation. He tried to take the bag from the employee, but the man resisted and attempted to strike Tenney in the face, according to testimony presented at Tenney's trial last month and reviewed at his sentencing. Tenney fled on foot without the money.

Title: Warden guilty in pet killings Man gets one year probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: Pleasant Point Police Chief Joseph Barnes said Clayton Sockabasin, 32, pleaded guilty to one count of cruelty to animals and one count of violating tribal hunting ordinances shortly after his trial began in Passamaquoddy Tribal Court at Indian Township. Barnes - who is also the chief administrator of the Passamaquoddy Warden Service at Pleasant Point - said Sockabasin pleaded guilty to two of the charges in exchange for a $500 suspended fine and one year of probation. Barnes said in an interview last March that Sockabasin used a conibear trap - also called a killer type because of strong jaws that snap or break the neck of an animal. He baited the trap and set it up in his garage, leaving the garage door partially open, the chief said.
Authors: Clancy, Mary Anne;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: Ex-Maine woman slain in Florida shooting Former fire chief remains on probation: [4 Edition]
Abstract: The shooting occurred after an argument erupted when [Julianne Fournier Stimus] went to [Aaron Stimus]'s residence across the street from where she lived to retrieve their 11-year-old daughter, according to police. The daughter witnessed the shooting, they said. The couple, who were in the process of divorcing, also have a 9-year-old son. The children remained with neighbors pending the arrival of relatives.

Title: New Showtime sci-fi adventure well-conceived, shows promise: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Peter Weller], who is best-known as the title character in the sci-fi films "Robocop" and "Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai," is outstanding as Taggart, who's more comfortable with the dangers of space than he is as a parent, including communicating with his crewmate and son Noel (Christopher Gorman, "Popular"). Also premiering on Showtime this weekend is a penetrating look at the federal parole system. Shot in a gritty documentary style, "Street Time," which debuts at 10 p.m. Sunday, examines parole from the perspectives of both the parolee and the parole officer. Scott Cohen ("NYPD Blue," "Gilmore Girls") stars as James Liberti, [Kevin Hunter]'s parole officer who has a habit of his own to kick. Liberti keeps trying to rehabilitate his parolees, not just revoke their probations and send them back. This attitude clashes with many of those around him. Of a similar mind is Dee Mulhern (Erika Alexander), a streetwise parole officer who worked hard to escape the circumstances that drive many to crime.

Title: Maine woman gets probation in warehouse fire: [All Edition]
Abstract: Worcester County District Attorney John Conte agreed to a "deferred dismissal" of the charges, Louis Aloise, King's attorney, said Thursday, reached at his office in Worcester. He said King has expressed remorse for her involvement in starting the fire even though she is not legally responsible for the deaths of six firefighters who entered the burning warehouse. King, then known as Julie Ann Barnes, and [Thomas Levesque] allegedly started the Dec. 3, 1999, blaze that killed six firefighters at the abandoned Worcester Cold Storage warehouse when they knocked over a candle during an argument. Prosecutors accused the couple, who were homeless at the time, of fleeing the warehouse without reporting the fire to authorities. Julie King, who now works at Holiday Inn in Ellsworth, is relieved she will not have to return to prison in Massachusetts, where she gave birth to a son fathered by Levesque, King said. The infant son, named Joshua, is in a foster home in Massachusetts.

Title: Turning the page Reading group provides literary mission for people on probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: Larry Cyr had a dream when he was a kid. He wanted to play baseball. And maybe, after that, become a cop. More than anything he wanted to be a good dad because his own father had disappeared to jail for most of Cyr's life. But Cyr's dream got deferred. Cyr is no longer in a prison cell. In fact, the day we met he was at a book discussion group with three other men on probation and Margery Irvine, a professor of English. Cyr was sharing his delight about spending Easter with his daughter - for the first time in years - and coaching her in farm league baseball. When they meet for just over an hour on Monday evenings at the Bangor Department of Corrections on the Bangor Mental Health Institute campus, the participants share their thoughts and listen to the way others see the same story. "I think it's good seeing other people's points of view," said [Phil Candelemo]. "Even if I disagree with Larry, it's good."
