Title: Former fire chief denies sex charge, probation violation Lawyer claims 'significant proof issues': [3 Edition]
Abstract: Malcolm "Mack" S. Hyler, 56, appeared in Knox County Superior Court with his attorney, Rick Morse of Rockland, to respond to a probation revocation order filed by his probation officer. A Thomaston man accused Hyler of sexually assaulting him last month at Hyler's Water Street apartment. Hyler was arrested, but documents pertaining to that allegation have been impounded. Earlier this week the alleged victim failed to win a permanent protection- from-harassment order he had requested against Hyler. During Hyler's initial appearance on the probation matter Thursday, Justice Joseph Jabar set bail at $1,000 unsecured until a hearing is held. And Hyler is to have no contact with the alleged victim. No date for the hearing has been set.
Authors: Robicheau, Leanne M;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: Tip leads to arrest of sex offender ; The Bay State man is arrested in a parking lot in Gray while traveling with two teen-age girls.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Thanks to a tip from an alert Cumberland Farms clerk, a registered sex offender from Massachusetts was arrested this week in [Gray] while traveling with two teen-age girls. [Mohammed Nassery], who's 39, is a registered sex offender in Massachusetts as a result of a rape conviction in 1993. One of the conditions of his parole in 1999 was that he not leave the state without authorization. Don Giancioppo, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Parole Board, said Mohammed Nassery had been attending sex-offender group counseling regularly since his release from prison in 1993. But now, he is facing another three years in prison for violating conditions of his parole, Giancioppo said.

Abstract: In July 2000, [Malcolm "Mack" Hyler], 56, pleaded guilty to seven counts of gross sexual assault against a 16-year-old boy and six counts of unlawful sexual contact with a 14-year-old boy. The offenses with the older boy occurred four years before Hyler's arrest. According to a court document filed last week in Knox County Superior Court, probation officer John Lorenzen is seeking to revoke Hyler's probation because of an alleged assault, which is considered failure to refrain from criminal conduct.

Title: Former fire chief arrested at home Thomaston man convicted of sex offense charged with probation violation: [3 Edition]
Abstract: THOMASTON - Former Fire Chief Malcolm "Mack" Hyler, who pleaded guilty two years ago to raping a teen-age boy, was arrested Wednesday night at his Water Street home on a probation violation. As Hyler's vehicle was being searched, a Thomaston police cruiser moved to the front of the apartment house, and Hyler came out of a door, running and unescorted. He appeared to be handcuffed. After he descended a slight incline, he got into the cruiser. Hyler, 56, pleaded guilty in July 2000 to seven counts of gross sexual assault against a 16-year-old boy and six counts of unlawful sexual contact with a 14-year-old boy. The offenses with the older male occurred four years before Hyler's initial arrest.
Authors: Robicheau, Leanne M;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: Maine State Prison demolition begins $1,474,000 project to last through summer: [All Edition]
Abstract: H.E. Sargent Inc. of Stillwater, which was awarded the demolition bid for $1,474,000, expects the project to last through the summer, project manager Jim Conley said. From now through the end of the project, the estimated 25,000 cubic yards of bricks, steel bars and other debris from the prison will be pushed into the quarry, and another 75,000 cubic yards of fill material will be hauled in to fill the massive pit. A portion of the perimeter wall near the prison showroom will remain standing and a commemorative plaque will be attached to remind people of the prison that housed some of Maine's most hardened criminals. The showroom on Route 1, which took in $1.6 million last year, will remain. A maintenance shop adjacent to the west wall, and several buildings across Route 1, which house probation and parole offices, also will stay. Some of the inside has been documented on film.
Authors: Robicheau, Leanne M;OF THE NEWS STAFF

Title: COMPANY, PRESIDENT ADMIT TO POLLUTING ; Saying he's `glad this nightmare is behind me,' Durastone's James Duhamel gets four years' probation and must pay restitution and fines.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: The decision comes nearly three years after investigators found that a company drainage pipe was leaking hydrochloric acid onto "adjacent wetland and the waters of the United States," according to the U.S. Attorney's Office. Assistant U.S. Attorney David Collins attributed the sentencing delay to a lengthy investigation that was further complicated by Durastone's bankruptcy problems. In exchange for Durastone's departure and cleanup, the city of Portland dropped its claim to a $200,000 bond the company had posted. After tests showed that cleanup was complete, the Department of Environmental Protection also dropped its claim to the bond. Durastone is now located on Wallace Avenue in South Portland. Megquier Hill Farm, a company that turns unused baked goods into a grain-like product, is now located at the Milliken Street site.

Title: Relative hopes to immortalize notorious uncle: [All Edition]
Abstract: A witness said she saw a man who resembled [Heald Jr.] fire two shots into [Edna Hamilton]'s back. Heald was charged with Hamilton's murder, but never prosecuted in [Mariba Beard]'s death. An all-male jury - despite having several witnesses and even the murder weapon to work with - convicted Heald only of the lesser charge of manslaughter. In 1975, Heald made headlines again for the role he played as mediator in a prison uprising and as a legal adviser and advocate for inmate rights. When three inmates took over the Thomaston prison's east wing, with a guard as their hostage, Heald quelled the potentially deadly situation by calling in Bangor Daily News Rockland bureau reporter Ted Sylvester to help in the negotiations. At 6-foot- 6 and 240 pounds, Heald was a fiercely imposing figure who assured the reporter that he would be safe inside. Later that year, Gov. James B. Longley commuted Heald's sentence to five to 30 years. In 1977, Heald was released on parole. A year after that, he was arrested again in connection with an armed robbery and assault at a New Hampshire motel, and was sent to the Concord Reformatory. Released in the mid-1980s, Heald managed to stay out of trouble for the remainder of his days.

Title: Tear gas ends standoff in Addison Shooter charged with probation violation after threat to shoot police: [All Edition]

She reported that Hanning was inside their trailer with a gun, Sgt. Michael Crabtree of the Washington County Sheriff's Department said. The sergeant said Beverly told him that she and Hanning had been arguing, and she had told him she was leaving. After Beverly went to the neighbor's house to call police, she said, she heard a shot fired from inside the trailer. She also warned police that Hanning had threatened to shoot police if they came to his trailer.

Title: County counterfeiters get two years probation: [1 Edition]
Abstract: Joseph Thayer, 22, who gave his apartment address as Caribou, earlier pleaded guilty to three counts. Title: Teen-ager on probation charged in weekend burglary: [York Edition]

Title: Bills alter approach in cases of abuse ; Proposals include hiring six investigators to build domestic violence cases that will stand up in court, and adding probation officers. Series: State House '02: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Perhaps even more important, [Lois Galgay Reckitt] said, is hiring probation officers to work solely on domestic violence cases. With the ability to send someone to jail, a probation officer can play a big role in ending a cycle of abuse. Another proposal of the commission would change a perceived flaw in the bail system. Under current law, anyone who needs bail after the courts are closed arranges it with a court-appointed bail commissioner, who receives a fee paid by the defendant. If the person can't afford bail, the commissioner doesn't get paid, which some people see as an incentive to set bail too low. The proposal to have the court system pay bail commissioner fees would also make the commissioners look more official, which could make batterers take bail conditions more seriously, Reckitt said.

Title: Man sentenced in crash that killed his brother Driver gets 36 months in jail, 6 years of probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: Talgo, slouching in his seat and appearing subdued, did not address the court, but several members of his family did before [Ellen Gorman] announced the young man's sentence. Talgo's three brothers, Aaron, Craig and Jason Talgo and his mother, Phyllis Talgo, all asked Gorman for leniency. Gorman said, however, that Talgo's drug offenses and two incidents since the fatal accident in which Talgo was caught speeding were aggravating factors in his sentencing. She said he is an appropriate candidate for probation but that Talgo needs to learn how to function within the legal bounds of society. Talgo was driving a 1998 Kia Sephia at nearly 90 mph in a 45 mph zone when the accident occurred, according to police. In the car besides [Alan Leif Talgo] and [Vaughn Talgo] were their brother Craig Talgo, 19, Jason Littlefield, 16, and Christopher Riley, 20. Talgo was reportedly speeding because the occupants were late to work in Stonington.

Title: Closed-door changes threaten nation's liberty, justice: [All Edition]
Abstract: Americans would be incensed if a such a justice system had been used against the U.S. airmen and women who were captured when their aircraft was forced to land in China earlier this year. Although these Americans eventually were released through intense diplomatic efforts, a New York woman charged with aiding terrorists in Peru was not so lucky. Lori Berenson was convicted of treason and sentenced to life without parole in a trial conducted by hooded military judges who barred cross-examination of witnesses. Only after years of pressure from Washington was she granted a civilian court retrial. How could we have made such a plea unless we passed the test ourselves? To be sure, in times of war, presidents have cut constitutional corners. In hindsight, however, we view these acts as shortsighted. During the Civil War, Abraham Lincoln suspended the writ of habeas corpus, the ancient right to court review of arbitrary governmental actions. President Franklin Delano Roosevelt ordered the trial by secret military tribunal of German saboteurs who were captured in New York. But as Peter Cox, the son of the U.S. prosecutor in that case, recently wrote in the Portland Press Herald, "The secrecy surrounding those events ... has left me wondering not if they were guilty but whether the process and punishment were just. Uncertainty is the price we pay for secrecy." FDR also allowed the detention of 100,000 law-abiding Japanese-Americans in internment camps for the duration of World War II. Decades later, Congress formally apologized and authorized the payment of reparations.

Title: PULLED GUN IN ALABAMA TIPPED POLICE TO SUSPECT ; Jeffrey 'Russ' Gorman, wanted for violating his probation, arrives back in Maine on Friday night.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: The report clicked because the department had been asked by Maine authorities to keep watch for Jeffrey "Russ" Gorman, a Troy native known to police there. Gorman was wanted in Maine for violating probation, but he also had been identified as a prime suspect in the disappearance of Amy St. Laurent. Gorman, eventually apprehended in Troy, arrived back in Maine on Friday night in the company of state probation officers. He was being held without bail at the Cumberland County Jail. [Christopher Ross] tried to convince a friend, Shawn Littlefield, not to accompany Gorman when the latter headed south last month, saying Gorman was a bad influence.

Title: Suspect in St. Laurent slaying sought for violation of probation ; Maine police notify other agencies that they want Jeffrey Gorman arrested and held until he's extradited.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: The arrest warrant notifies any law enforcement agency that if [Jeffrey Gorman] is located, he should be held without bail for extradition to Maine. The motion for a warrant from the Maine Department of Corrections probation division alleges that Gorman violated his probation by failing to report as required, failing to notify the state of a change in address, leaving the state without permission, and not reporting numerous contacts with police during October and November. The probation stems from a year-old theft conviction. It was in the paperwork supporting the initial warrant that a probation officer's notation indicated Gorman was the primary suspect in the case.

Title: Junkyard owner back in jail Meddybemps man violates probation, says cleanup under way: [1 Edition]
Abstract: Judge Andrew Mead told Harry Smith Jr. that Smith would have to decide, upon his release, whether he would begin fulfilling the terms of his probation or continue to serve his sentence "on the installment plan." Smith is on probation for his 1999 conviction on two charges of violating a state order to stop accepting used tires at his junkyard on Route 191. At the time of the 1997 order, the Maine Department of Environmental Protection estimated there were 1 million used tires at Smith's junkyard. Smith said he called [William Love] as instructed, but the line was busy and he had gone back to helping the DEP with his cleanup operation. There was a trailer truck blocking Route 191 and he wanted to get it off the road, Smith said.

Title: Judge says probation still in effect for rapist: [All Edition]
Abstract: In a written decision filed late last week, Justice Andrew Mead stated that errors had been made in previous court hearings regarding [Clayton Byrum]'s probation, but he said the probation remains in effect. Deputy District Attorney Michael Roberts has expressed great concern about keeping a watch on Byrum, who he said is an untreated sex offender. When Officer George Spencer arrived at the Finson Road park, there was no yelling, just the man leaning over the 43-year-old [Sheryl Bassett] who apparently passed out. Title: Costly death: [All Edition]
Abstract: Actually, the reverse is true. A study at Duke University has found that the death penalty costs North Carolina $2.16 million per execution over the costs of a non-death penalty murder case with a sentence of life imprisonment. In Texas, a death-penalty case costs an average of $2.3 million, about three times the cost of imprisoning someone in a single cell at the highest security level for 40 years. A study of 44 Florida executions since 1976 found that they cost $51 million a year above and beyond what it would have cost to punish all first-degree murderers with life in prison without parole.

Title: ONE MORE CHANCE FOR OFFENDER? Norman Dickinson has spent most of his life in prison and repeatedly violated probation. Now his fate is up to a judge.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Although [Norman Dickinson] has failed to follow the rules of probation in the past, the judge said it is worth trying again. "At some point, Mr. Dickinson is going to be among us, and it serves everyone's interest to be sure that when it happens, he has the best therapeutic foundation," he said. He has a social anxiety disorder, substance abuse disorder and uses sexual exhibitionism as a "self-soothing mechanism," said Steven Thomas, a social worker who has evaluated Dickinson. He said many of Dickinson's problems result from his near-lifetime in prison. Because Dickinson is a former resident of the Augusta Mental Health Institute, he is eligible for community-based mental health services when he is released from prison. His lawyer, Neale Duffett, argued that Dickinson should be released to finish his probation where he can get the help he needs.

Title: FATHER GETS TWO YEARS FOR BURNING INFANT SON Jeremy Oliver of Standish enters a plea agreement that calls for four years' probation and psychiatric treatment, and could be free in eight months.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: She said since Oliver had a history of mental illness preceding the crime against his child, he could have been acquitted by reason of insanity if he had gone to trial. But in January, Oliver gave up his right to a trial and entered a plea agreement with prosecutors to reduce his maximum sentence from 10 years in prison to five years. At that time, [Roland Cole] asked for further psychiatric evaluations of Oliver. The examination found Oliver "to be competent to assist his counselor for trial," said Cole on Friday. "But he doesn't want a trial." Cole agreed with [Meg Elam]'s request to move forward with a guilty plea rather than risk bringing Oliver to trial. Cole read the terms of Oliver's probation twice to make sure he understood them clearly. Cole said Oliver's probation, the maximum for his sentence, was necessary because "he has a high risk of re- offending." If Oliver fails to follow the terms of his probation, Cole said he could serve his full five-year sentence.

Title: STRAIN ON PROBATION SYSTEM RECOMMENDS NEW SOLUTIONS Do Mainers really want to build more jails for petty violations?: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: According to a recent Maine Sunday Telegram story, much of the jail space crunch in the state is attributable to a crackdown on probation violators. The state has hired more probation officers and has stepped up enforcement. As a result, they are catching more former prisoners breaking the terms of their probation. Such violations now account for half of the prison population in the Kennebec County jail and 40 percent of the prisoners in Androscoggin County.

Title: BRINGING VIOLATORS TO JUSTICE ADDS UP Jails are crowding and taxpayers are picking up the bill as the state gets tough with probation violators.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: Half the people in his jail were either convicted of a probation violation, accused of it or have been denied bail because they are on probation and committed another offense. That costs taxpayers money. If individuals on probation are arrested again for another offense, or are charged with violating probation, they are taken to county jail and held there pending a hearing on the charge. They are usually ineligible for bail and so are kept in jail, sometimes for months, until a new hearing is held. The changes have been praised by law enforcement and prosecutors as giving more teeth to the state's probation system and representing greater truth in sentencing. Corrections officials lack statewide numbers, but jail officials across the Maine say the number of people charged with violating probation continues to climb, contributing to the overcrowding at many of Maine's county lockups.
Authors: DAVID HENCH Staff Writer Susan Butler, library assistant, contributed research to this story.

Title: Winterport man faces drug, probation charges: [4 Edition]
Abstract: [Peter Spann] was on probation for an earlier drug arrest when the detectives made their unannounced visit to his home. The probation check was authorized by Spann's probation officer, Eric Harvey, and was part of a continuing effort between the sheriff's office and Maine Probation and Parole to assure individuals released from jail or prison are abiding by the terms of their probation.

Title: Violation of probation returns Monson teen to detention center: [All Edition]
Abstract: [Bridget Burke] had been sitting with Reed in the Reed family pickup truck in front of the Monson Laundromat when the boy shot her in the chest with a .38-caliber revolver he found in the glove compartment. He said later that he didn't know the gun was loaded. Since his release, however, Reed has failed to abide by the probation requirements, it was noted in court Monday. On at least two occasions, Reed was in possession of alcohol and at least three times, he failed a urine test, Assistant Attorney General Andrew Benson said Monday, in a courtroom filled with relatives of both Reed and the slain girl. Both Benson and Reed's attorney, David Gray of Dover-Foxcroft, agreed that Reed's problem with alcohol would best be addressed by terminating his probation and ordering him to serve his underlying sentence at the Maine Youth Center until his 18th birthday.
subjectTerms: Reed, Jesse , Burke, Bridget , Benson, Andrew

Title: Probation violations land criminal back in jail: [4 Edition]
Abstract: The standoff, for which [James Farnham] served nine months, mostly in a Portland halfway house, occurred when Farnham barricaded himself in an apartment on Bolling Drive in Bangor and refused to come out or to talk with federal agents for four hours. Members of the Bangor Special Response Tactical Team had to break down the door to reach Farnham shortly after noon that day. Earlier in the day Farnham had failed to show up for a federal court appearance, resulting in an arrest warrant. [Margaret J. Kravchuk] granted Bangor defense attorney Perry O'Brian's request to research places where Farnham could stay pending further court action. His grandparents in Levant have housed him before and are "responsible people," the judge said. Yet they are elderly and have health problems and another grandson to deal with at this point, the judge noted.

Title: Thomaston inmates double up in cells: [All Edition]
Abstract: The primary cause of the current overcrowding is the 1995 change in sentencing policy regarding "good time" credit earned by prisoners, Lord said. Legislation reduced the amount of days taken off inmates' sentences each month for good behavior. Lord also pointed to the 1976 abolishment of parole in Maine as another reason the state has retained more prisoners. [Larry L. Richardson] died while he was imprisoned with another inmate in a segregation unit at the maximum-security prison. His cellmate and another inmate were charged with murder. Lawyers for the two inmates alleged that prison employees were negligent because they failed to protect Richardson, despite knowing that he had a history of suicide attempts and had been a target of harassment by other inmates. The overflow of inmates is coming primarily from the Maine Correctional Center in South Windham, which has been double- and triple-bunking prisoners, [Warden Jeffrey Merrill] said. That institute gets more inmates because it houses offenders who have been sentenced to less than eight years.
Authors: Robicheau, Leanne M;Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Merrill, Warden Jeffrey , Barkan, Steven , Sturks, James , Richardson, Larry L

Title: MCVEIGH'S STAY OF EXECUTION REVIVES DEATH PENALTY DISPUTE What should society do to both punish murderers and protect itself?: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: [William Tucker] concludes, "The one ray of hope has been in the recent rise of executions. Publicizing of the death penalty seems to be penetrating the criminal mind. As executions have risen steeply in the mid-1990s, the murder rate has dropped precipitously. We are at least back to a level of 1969 - still more than double the days when the death penalty was routinely enforced, but well below the peak of the execution-free 1980s." This is the essence of the Catholic view. While giving all murderers life without parole is a sound principle, we are so far from it in practical terms that we will be living in hanging gardens on the moon before it becomes general law. Remember the six-year murder sentences, and the 821 victims of already-convicted murderers? That's the reality we face. Meanwhile, my friends who are murderers are safe - Maine hasn't had the death penalty for more than a century. But compassion for the murderers you know has to be weighed in the balance with greater compassion for the victims you never met - and for the potential victims who will remain alive if killers can never kill again.

Title: MARGARET ANDERSON, 81, SCHOOLTEACHER, PROBATION OFFICER: [FINAL EDITION]
Abstract: Surviving are two daughters, Karen V. Douglass of South Portland and Nancy A. Downs of Brunswick; two sisters, Flora E. Marley of New Smyrna Beach, Fla., and Sebago, and Grace B. Gilpatrick of South Hiram; and four grandchildren. She graduated from the Northeastern School of Accounting in 1950, received her bachelor of science degree in education from the University of Maine in 1967 and her master's in education in 1970 from the University of Maine at Portland-Gorham (now the University of Southern Maine). She also graduated from a special criminal justice program at American University in Washington, D.C., in 1969.

Title: Death penalty bill denied House rejects proposal to execute child killers: [All Edition]
Abstract: The chairman of that committee, Rep Edward Povich, D-Ellsworth, agreed that the murder of child is a "horrible crime no matter what the age," but the death penalty does not serve as a deterrent. The committee heard expert testimony that the death penalty is more expensive to administer than life without parole, can be applied with racial bias and can result in gross miscarriage of justice when an innocent person is executed. Sending an innocent person to execution is the "ultimate miscarriage of justice," Povich said Research cited during a recent committee hearing disclosed 400 cases of innocent prisoners being executed during the 20th century, Povich said. In Oklahoma alone, a dozen men on death row were set free when it was determined that a police chemist falsified testimony, Povich said.
subjectTerms: Mello, Lois Snowe- , Palmer, Angela , Povich, Edward

Title: Enfield boy admits taking gun to school 11-year-old sentenced to 2 years probation: [All Edition]
Abstract: Appearing in 13th District Court in Lincoln on Tuesday, Justin Landry, through his attorney, James C. Munch III, of Bangor, changed his earlier plea where he denied two felony charges of reckless conduct in connection with the discharge of a firearm at the Enfield Station Elementary School on March 21 and the charge of possessing a firearm on public school property. [Dan Wood] said [Landry] took the gun to school and on the bus ride showed it to another pupil. Later in a school bathroom, he and another pupil "played around" with the gun. When Landry was alone in the restroom, he loaded the gun and fired it directly into the floor, said the assistant district attorney. Judge Kevin Stitham agreed to the sentence recommended by Wood. Landry, accompanied by Munch, approached the judge, who told Landry that if he violated the terms of his probation during the next two years, he risked going to the Maine Youth Center.
Authors: Lagasse, Mary Anne;Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Munch, James C III , Wood, Dan

Title: Bar Harbor resident faces multiple charges: [3 Edition]
Abstract: Monday afternoon, [Jon Turner] was arrested for violating his parole, and on new charges of burglary and criminal mischief, when police said he broke into and vandalized the apartment of an acquaintance on Paluga Lane in Bar Harbor after being released from the hospital.

Title: Little League girls' coaches in raffle rift Four in Westbrook are on probation for a protest over perceived inequity.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: Each division of the Westbrook Little League holds its own raffle. But the boys' Little League raffle is held first, and it features prizes awarded to top sellers on opening day. The girls' softball raffle is just starting. The girls also can earn prizes. But on opening day, all they can do is watch the boys collect their prizes in front of hundreds of fans. In February, the softball coaches had asked some members of the league's board of directors if they could be included in the boys' raffle and if the girls could have a chance to win prizes on opening day, just like the boys. The softball coaches wanted a unified, all- league raffle. So [Pete Wescott], [Roger Morse] and their supporters remained outside for two hours while the board met. When [George Apt] emerged from the meeting, he told the crowd that Wescott, Morse and two other softball coaches whose teams had participated in the walkout were on probation for the season. He told the crowd that the men could coach during the regular season, but were banned from coaching in the state playoffs.
subjectTerms: Wescott, Pete , Morse, Roger , Apt, George

Title: Killer on probation faces jail time: [3 Edition]
Abstract: In 1998, [Floyd Firth Jr.] was ordered to serve seven days in jail for writing bad checks. Last November, he tested positive for marijuana and struck a deal that allowed him to remain free for three months. If Firth could stay out of trouble during that period, his sentence would be 60 days in jail. He is due in court today for that sentencing. On April 20, Firth was arrested in Damariscotta for OUI and possession of liquor, [Lara Nomani] said. Nomani said Firth's blood alcohol level was 0.13. The legal limit in Maine is 0.08. She asked the court to deny bail. Defense attorney William Pagnano said his client had been out of jail for five years and that none of his "falling offs" in the past year involved violence. He argued that Firth has strong ties to the community and owns property in Damariscotta. Pagnano told the judge Firth was a student of his when he taught at Rockland District High School.
Authors: Robicheau, Leanne M;Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Drug legalization , Firth, Floyd Jr , Atwood, John , Nomani, Lara

Title: Excessive jail term prompts inquiry at Bangor facility: [All Edition]
Abstract: The recent incident has prompted the jail to review its procedures when releasing an inmate at the request of local probation officers, according to Penobscot County Sheriff's Department Capt. Cheryl Gallant, who confirmed Friday that the department had begun an internal investigation into a case in which an inmate was "inadvertently" held at the jail. Charles O'Roak, regional correctional administrator for the Department of Corrections Bangor-based probation and parole bureau, said his department, too, would review its procedures when requesting the release of a person picked up on a probation hold. In a system in which probation officers and jail personnel often are on first-name bases, O'Roak said the local department does not require a written authorization of release. However, O'Roak said he would meet with jail officials next week to discuss measures both departments could take to ensure the situation does not repeat itself.
subjectTerms: Gallant, Cheryl , O Roak, Charles , Davis, Tom

Title: BONNY EAGLE TAKEN OFF PROBATION, BUT RETAINS `WARNING' STATUS An accrediting agency says the school has fixed many problems but must still demonstrate progress in two key areas.: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: "Probation says, you're not living up to our standards. A warning says, you've put things in place, and you'll remain on warning until you show us the plan is working." Phil Blood, assistant superintendent Bonny Eagle High School has corrected enough academic and building shortcomings to be removed from probation by a regional accrediting agency. The school will remain on warning status with the New England Association of Schools and Colleges until at least March 2002. That's when the association will review Bonny Eagle's progress in improving its curriculum and assessment of student learning. "Probation says, you're not living up to our standards," Assistant Superintendent Phil Blood said. "A warning says, you've put things in place, and you'll remain on warning until you show us the plan is working."

Title: Probation violation leads to detention Teen makes return trip to juvenile center: [1 Edition]
Abstract: He will appear Friday in District Court in Caribou on the first alleged violation of probation, which reportedly occurred on Feb. 27. He was charged last Tuesday, March 14, with a second violation of probation, and returned to the juvenile center on Wednesday, according to Assistant District Attorney Rob Langner. On Feb. 27, [Nathan Anderson] was charged with violation of probation for being out of his parents' home while under house arrest. Anderson has denied the allegation, which will be dealt with in court Friday. The probation violation of March 14 allegedly involved the consumption of alcohol, Langner said. Anderson reportedly admitted to the violation and was returned to the detention center.

Title: Funeral director violates probation: [1 Edition]
Abstract: Rather than undergo a drug test last month, as required by conditions of his probation, Lancaster voluntarily admitted to using marijuana, according to court records. The funeral director also turned over a bag containing three-fourths of an ounce of the drug and a pipe used to smoke the drug, court records said. The probation revocation hearing was held March 7 in Maine District Court in Fort Kent before Judge Ronald A. Daigle.

Title: 'NO ARREST' EDICT DRAWS CRITICISM Some officials are concerned that probation officers are told not to arrest juvenile clients.: [Final Edition]
Abstract: The Department of Corrections says the change, which has been in effect three weeks, is intended to make better use of the time and training of juvenile community corrections officers. If they manage their caseload well, juvenile crime and the societal costs associated with it will decrease, says Barry Stoodley, associate commissioner of the Department of Corrections. The number of arrests made by a juvenile probation officer varies widely from almost none to two or three a month, officials say. The numbers tend to be higher in cities, where a probation officer is more likely to encounter youths outside the office. Stoodley cited North Dakota, where juvenile caseworkers do not have powers of arrest but focus solely on managing their clients' cases. In that state recidivism is among the lowest in the country, compared to Maine - which he believes is relatively high. The state lacks statistics on juvenile recidivism in Maine, though it has started such tracking, he said.

Title: Drug possession charge follows probation arrest: [3 Edition]
Abstract: When Deputy Tim Cote arrived, he found [Bruce Smith] lying on the floor next to a local woman he was not permitted to see, according to his probation. Cote also smelled liquor in the room. He asked Smith if the conditions of his probation were clear. Smith said yes, that he had not been drinking because he knew it to be a violation.

Title: Behind bars, again Activists who vandalized BIW destroyer head back to prison: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: Berrigan's and [Susan Crane]'s sentences in the BIW incident included supervised release, with conditions requiring them to pay restitution and refrain from similar acts in the future. Berrigan also represented himself. He spoke more briefly than Crane, admitting to his actions but saying he does "not recognize the right of the U.S. government to protect those horrid airplanes with the law." Staff photo by John Ewing Activist [Philip Berrigan] talks to the media Friday outside U.S. District Court in Portland. He and Susan Crane were sentenced to 12 months in federal prison for violating conditions of their probation. Staff photo by John Ewing Protesters try to make their point Friday outside U.S. District Court in Portland, where Philip Berrigan and Susan Crane were attending a parole violation hearing. The two had been freed two weeks ago after serving more than a year in jail for a vandalism protest at Bath Iron Works in 1997.

Title: St. David dealer sentenced Probation violation nets 18 months in jail: [1 Edition]
Abstract: Jesse Green, 19, Caribou, assault, 120 days in jail; burglary, two years in jail, all but 120 days suspended, two years probation, $400 fine. Daniel Easler, 25, Mapleton, two counts of operating after revocation, six months in jail; three counts of criminal operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicants, six months in jail, $1,000 fine and four-year license suspension; operating after habitual offender, 60 days; violating a condition of release, 30 days. Brent Rafford, 28, Madawaska, revocation of probation, 12 months in jail; theft, 12 months; theft of services, 12 months; and two counts of attempted theft by deception, four months.

Title: Kenneth Ricker, artist, musician, youth chess coach: [FINAL Edition]
Abstract: Mr. Ricker's career in probation and parole began with his employment at the Cumberland County Juvenile Probation Department and continued into the state division of Probation and Parole. He retired in the 1970s as District 1 supervisor of the state division of Probation and Parole. Mr. Ricker had a lifelong passion for chess. A natural mentor who loved teaching others about the game, he coached a Cape Elizabeth chess club for school children into his 80s. "I want them to hold onto it and use it during their lifetimes," he said during an interview in 1989. "I like kids and I like chess. It's a happy marriage."

Title: Violation of probation yields 60 days for felony murderer: [3 Edition]
Abstract: [Floyd Firth Jr.] cooperated with prosecutors during the trials of co- defendants Earl A. Nash, 31, and Allen R. Teele, 31, who both are serving lengthy sentences at Maine State Prison in Thomaston. Nash and Teele are serving 20-year sentences. When Nash pleaded guilty, his sentencing included five other robberies. He had all but 17 years suspended from his term. Teele must serve 16 years in prison for felony murder, manslaughter and robbery.
Authors: Robicheau, Leanne M;Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Firth, Floyd Jr , Nash, Earl A , Teele, Allen R

Title: District attorney gets larger office Ellsworth staff moves to new building: [3 Edition]
Abstract: The offices for [Michael Povich] and his staff, which includes assistant district attorneys, victim-witness advocates and support staff, will be in the main portion of the building. In addition to the office space for the 11-person staff, the new space will provide enough space for a conference room and for much-needed storage, Povich said. Initially, the commissioners had considered leasing space in the ell of the building to the state for probation and parole officials. It does not appear that will happen now. Povich said the commissioners have considered that space as a possible site for a regional communications center. The move is going well, Povich said, thanks to the loan of a truck from Cubby Brown at Brown's Appliances. Povich expects to be settled by the end of this week.

Title: Man linked to murder faces probation revocation hearing: [3 Edition]
Abstract: It took nearly three years for police to find out that [Floyd Firth Jr.], [Earl A. Nash] and [Allen R. Teele] were responsible for Howard's death. The case had been considered an unattended, accidental death to that point. After the arrest of Dalton Malmstrom II, for an unrelated incident, Malmstrom told police that the trio had killed Howard, so he could lessen his own jail time. Nash had told him about the murder when the two shared a jail cell at one time. After serving his time, Firth was released on probation. But in April 1999, Firth violated his probation and was ordered to serve 7 days in jail for writing $1,571 in bad checks.
Authors: Robicheau, Leanne M;Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Firth, Floyd Jr , Nash, Earl A , Teele, Allen R

Title: St. Joseph's president reins in diversity group The Gay/Straight Alliance is on probation, facing a possible ban.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: The lectures sounded good to Professor Reg Hannaford -- one session on "Writing Diversity" and another on "Acting Diversity." The Gay/Straight Alliance at St. Joseph's College in Standish planned to co-sponsor the talks, and authors and actors had agreed to participate. The college president canceled the lectures, placed the alliance on probation and is considering kicking the year-old organization off- campus. Hannaford was so unhappy with President David House's decision to cancel the lectures, he held them at his home in Brunswick -- the second one was Monday night. Dan Neuville, who founded the Gay/Straight Alliance and is president of the college's Student Senate, acknowledged that the alliance has been disorganized and that its membership isn't huge, but he said the organization is important.

Title: Accused rapist jailed on probation violation
Abstract: In 1991, [Dennis Sirois] was sentenced to 20 years in prison with all but 15 years suspended. His probation required that he refrain from all criminal conduct or face serving the suspended portion of his sentence.

Title: Abuser to spend 3 years in prison 12 years of probation to follow
Abstract: Honoring a plea agreement between the District Attorney's Office and [Lewis Sapienza]'s lawyer, Justice Donald Marden on Thursday sentenced him to 15 years in prison, suspended after three years. Marden also ordered Sapienza to undergo sex offender counseling and to have no unsupervised contact with children younger than 14. Before sentencing, Marden had ordered Sapienza to undergo a psychological evaluation.
Authors: Mike Laberge Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Houlton police seek suspects in 2 cases One juvenile in custody after home break-in
Abstract: Police attempted to arrest Jeffrey Hardy, 43, at his former home Sunday morning. The violations for which he is being sought stem from a domestic assault conviction of a year ago. Hardy was described as an American Indian with a slender build. He is 5 feet 7 inches tall and weighs about 160 pounds. He has close- cropped, neat, dark hair and was last seen wearing a navy blue or black sweat shirt and black jeans. He is not considered dangerous. Police attempted to arrest Hardy when they learned he was at his former home, a violation of his parole and probation.
Authors: Beurmond Banville Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Suspect remains at large Hardy flees when police move in
Abstract: Members of the Houlton Police Department and the Maine State Police had gone to the home of Jeffrey Hardy, 43, at around 8 a.m. to arrest him on two counts of parole and probation violation stemming from a domestic assault conviction a year ago, Cpl. Terry Beaton of the Houlton Police Department said Sunday night. Hardy is described as an American Indian with a slender build. He is 5-feet-7-inches tall and weighs 160 pounds. Hardy has close- cropped, neat, dark hair and was last seen wearing a navy blue or black sweatshirt and black jeans. He is not considered dangerous.
Authors: Julia Bayly Of the NEWS staff

Title: Judge rules Saucier broke probation rules The jury in his manslaughter trial will continue deliberating today.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: [Joe-Pete Saucier] was on probation, and less than a month out of jail, when he allegedly led police on a nine-mile chase, crashed his pickup truck, and killed his passenger, 21-year-old Brandi Butterfield of Old Orchard Beach. Clifford Strike, Saucier's attorney, said during his closing argument that his client is innocent because Butterfield, not Saucier, was driving when the truck slammed into a concrete embankment and landed upside down in the Nonesuch River in Scarborough. Strike said that about half way through the police chase, probably on Winnocks Neck Road, Saucier switched positions with Butterfield, and she started to drive. He said Saucier asked her to switch because he was driving with a suspended license.

Title: Surprise from Rancid: New CD's one of the year's best While the Dandy Warhols turn in a similarly tasty effort, Earth Crisis misses the mark with 'Slither.': [CITY Edition]
Abstract: The genre-jumping career of Primal Scream defies easy description. But no matter what they've done, they've stayed close enough to mainstream audiences that their work has always held sway within the world of Britpop. With "XTRMNTR," the band's bonds with techno, always strong, again define the record. "XTRMNTR" wants to be a shot of uncompromising adrenaline to the increasingly introspective, brooding British music scene. "XTRMNTR" is calculatedly political, confrontational and extreme. "Subvert Normality," says a card on the inside, featuring a picture of a jumpsuit-clad flight crew loading a missile. There's also a postcard addressed to the London Parole Board, imploring that they release a convicted English murderer whose imprisonment, many feel, is race motivated. "XTRMNTR" features such song titles as "Kill All Hippies," "Swastika Eyes" and "Shoot Speed/Kill Light." The attitude is in place; how about the music? The Steely Dan stuff is notable if lightweight. Smashmouth and Marvelous 3, which both live and die by the hook, find two of best ones Dan ever made, in "Do It Again" and "Reelin' in the Years." The results are predictably pleasant, although they do raise the question: Why cover an unimprovable song, especially if you've got nothing new to add? Wilco gives a sweet "Any Major Dude," Ivy a seductively sardonic "Only a Fool." Up-and-comers The Push Stars contribute an appealing "Bad Sneakers," Billy Goodrum a similar "Razor Boy." Ben Folds Five, one of the few bands around as smart as Steely Dan, sounds right at home in "Barrytown," and the Brian Setzer Orchestra makes joyous swinging whoopee with "Bodhisattva."

Title: Construction problems delay new Houlton barracks Lieutenant hopes to be in
Abstract: The new building, which was designed by WBRC Architects and Engineers of Bangor, will replace the old barracks built more than 60 years ago. The facility will serve not only Troop F, but also detectives, the Maine Drug Enforcement Agency, State Fire Marshal's Office, and the Bureau of Liquor Enforcement, as well as the Warden Service, Maine Forest Service and Probation and Parole. It also will serve as the base for the region's Public Service Answering Point for the E-911 system. [Barry Smith] has argued, however, that when change orders were initiated, WBRC was sometimes late in getting those changes back to the contractor, which in turn, delayed portions of the project. Smith said Friday that while most of the other issues have been resolved, after a three-hour meeting Thursday between the state, [Herb Gibson] and [Jim Martin], the door issue has not yet been taken care of. He said WBRC and the brick mason are each blaming the other for the problem.
Authors: Wayne Brown Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Thomaston panel mulls fate of old prison: [2nd Edition]
Abstract: Tear it down, landscape the property and give it back to Thomaston, a town panel suggested as the state considers ways to reuse the 150-year-old Maine State Prison. The findings of the questionnaire also showed that many people want the probation office relocated elsewhere and that all prison properties on the north side of Route 1 be returned to private use, according to the report. The probation and parole office is situated in one of those buildings, as is housing previously used by the warden. Options for the buildings started at $1.3 million to "mothball" the facility and maintain it with minimum security. The most expensive alternative was estimated at $20 million and involves demolishing all buildings, filling a massive quarry and build a 16,000-square-foot office space and 100-unit senior citizen housing and assisted living facility.
Authors: Leanne M. Robicheau Of the NEWS Staff

Title: County mentors seek to halt repeat crimes: [AROOSTOOK Edition]
Abstract: Houlton Police Chief Darrell Malone, who is on the start-up committee in Houlton, said he sees the program as a good thing for Houlton and the region. Anyone interested in becoming a mentor in the southern Aroostook area can contact [Mark Nelson] at AMHC in Houlton at 532-6523. The program, which would serve junior high and high school age children in the Houlton area, uses volunteers who serve as mentors for juveniles referred to the program through the state probation and parole system.
Authors: Wayne L. Brown Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Wiggin, David , Nelson, Mark , Ayre, Richard , Malone, Darrell

Title: Probation violation nets arrest for kidnapper: [MID-MAINE Edition]
Abstract: [Norman Dickinson], who spent the last decade in prison after being convicted of kidnapping, robbery and criminal threatening, had been relocated to Lewiston by the state Department of Corrections, according to Police Chief William Welch.

Title: System tries, fails to stem tide of youth crime: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: "If you go down to Probation and Parole and say, 'Name five families -- five whole families that have gone the way of the Wests,' you would get a list of names from them," [Judy Ridge] said. "Then, you could come down here to the detective bureau and say it. They'd probably give you the same names." "Our concern," Ridge said, "is the safety of children -- not locking children up. But as they get older and they become involved in the system and they commit crimes, you bet your bottom dollar they do get locked up." There is a "therapeutic community" at the Maine Correctional Center in Windham that helps prepare inmates for productive lives on the outside. But she adds: "That's the best we can do, is to at least have those opportunities available and to create the right incentives so people do participate in their community."
subjectTerms: Ridge, Judy , Levin, Jack , West, Jamie

Title: Dunton sentenced for drug violation Judge sets tougher probation restrictions: [3rd Edition]
Abstract: Deputy Bill Flagg shot [Sidney Dunton] seven times on Jan. 27, when authorities said Dunton rammed Flagg's cruiser with his car and approached the deputy. At the time, Dunton was wielding what police later determined was a fake gun. Dunton reportedly threatened to kill Flagg. A representative of Volunteers of America, which oversees Dunton's bail, tried unsuccessfully to get a urine sample from Dunton earlier in the week. The representative returned to Dunton's home at Silver's Trailer Park last Friday, this time with Veazie police. Dunton provided authorities with a sample that morning, but police said the liquid was too clear and cool to be urine and suspected Dunton may have obtained the sample from the toilet. Officer Chris Greeley took Dunton to the Penobscot County Sheriff's Department where another sample was taken and tested three times.
Authors: Dawn Gagnon Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Dunton, Sidney , Flagg, Bill , Greeley, Chris

Title: Caribou funeral director gets probation: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: A subheadline on a story in Friday's MaineDay incorrectly stated the amount of a fine levied against a Caribou funeral director convicted of growing marijuana. John Lancaster was fined $1,900, as stated in the story. Lancaster's attorney, E. Allen Hunter of Caribou, said that his client endured a year of "significant distress," with the breakup of his marriage. The defense attorney said that his client's drug abuse did not interfere with his profession and that Lancaster is expected to retain his funeral services license. Lancaster's home and business were searched on May 25 by Maine Drug Enforcement Agency agents. Found at the residence were syringes used in drug production, plant seedlings in boxes, several plastic bags of marijuana and psilocybin mushrooms, a hallucinogen.
Authors: Debra Sund Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Lancaster, John , Head, Anne , Langner, Rob , Hunter, E Allen

Title: Palermo man gets 5 years' probation: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: Testimony from John Lorenz, a clinical psychologist, verified that [Everett Frank Garcelon] had suffered severe sexual abuse from his parents as a child, which may account for a predilection for child pornography. Garcelon has a low self-esteem level and a passive personality and is "unlikely to accost someone" which might differ in a person who is more aggressively motivated, Lorenz testified. In addition, the defendant has been in sex-offender treatment successfully for about 11 months at this point, which is an indicator of ongoing rehabiitation, according to Lorenz.
Authors: Nancy Garland Of the NEWS Staff
subjectTerms: Garcelon, Everett Frank , Carter, Gene , Lorenz, John

Title: Bush disputes execution probe Newspaper examines Texas record: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: The death penalty is likely to become part of the presidential campaign between [Barbara Bush], a Republican, and Democratic Vice President Al Gore. Like Bush, Gore supports the death penalty, but he has never held an office where he would authorize an execution or grant clemency. In individual cases, he can grant clemency -- life in prison -- upon the recommendation of the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles, or grant a one-time, 30-day reprieve. Bush has exercised each power once. He issued his first reprieve, for Ricky McGinn, on June 1. Bush also can order an investigation. Bush declined to be interviewed for the Tribune story. His criminal justice policy director, Johnny Sutton, said Bush views his role in the execution process as that of a "safety valve."
subjectTerms: Bush, George W , Spence, David Wayne , Gore, Albert Jr , Sutton, John , Bush, Barbara

Title: Two charged in '63 race bombing Prosecutors aren't saying what led to the arrest of two ex-Klansmen now, after 37 years.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: Two former Ku Klux Klansmen were arrested on murder charges Wednesday in the 1963 Birmingham church bombing that killed four black girls on a Sunday morning -- a crime that shocked the nation and galvanized the civil rights movement. Thomas E. Blanton Jr., 61, of Birmingham, and Bobby Frank Cherry, 69, of Mabank, Texas, surrendered on the state charges and were jailed without bail. If convicted, they could get life in prison with the possibility of parole. Prosecutors have long suspected that Blanton and Cherry plotted with former Klansman Robert Edward Chambliss to bomb the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church. Chambliss was convicted in 1977 and died in prison in 1985. A fourth suspect, Herman Cash, was never charged; he, too, is dead.

Title: Rockport physician faces probation: [3rd Edition]
Abstract: The state Board of Licensure in Medicine reached consensus Tuesday that Dr. Robert Phelps, who admits his wrongdoing, will be on probation indefinitely, be required to continue counseling at least twice a month, have his work professionally monitored, be accompanied by a chaperone when meeting with female patients, and take on four years of education on proper boundaries with patients. The board could have revoked Phelps' license to practice medicine in Maine, an option that is being held in abeyance, noted a board member. Phelps has admitted to having a sexual relationship with one patient, who his attorney said also knew Phelps from working at the local hospital. The attorney said the woman pursued the relationship with Phelps.
Authors: Tom Groening Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Poacher with long record sentenced to year in jail Bradford man must pay fines, serve probation: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: Peter Badger, 40, of Bradford, who in past years has been convicted of six counts of night hunting and 14 other major fish and game violations, pleaded guilty Thursday in Penobscot County Superior Court to two counts of night hunting and one count of possession of a firearm by a felon. Badger also will serve four years of probation with special conditions. These include that he have no firearms in his residence or in his possession, that he allow random searches of his home and property if wardens suspect him of violating fish and game laws, and that he abide by a curfew during hunting season. "The game wardens consider him to be one of the most notorious poachers that they've ever had to deal with in their careers," Greg Campbell, Penobscot County assistant district attorney, said Friday. Badger's violations go back almost 20 years and include six previous night-hunting cases, Campbell said.
Authors: Diana Bowley Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Court nixes appeal by murderer: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: The Supreme Judicial Court on Friday denied the appeal of a Florida man convicted of killing a nurse who was raped and found shot to death in Norridgewock in 1976, a crime solved decades later by means of DNA evidence. After a nine-day jury trial last May, Albert P. Cochran, 61, of Stuart, Fla., was convicted of the murder of Janet Baxter, 30, of Oakland, who was abducted from a Waterville parking lot on Nov. 23, 1976. Her body was recovered from the trunk of a car found along the Kennebec River. He challenged his conviction on three issues: admissibility of hearsay testimony offered by the defense, the trial judge's denial of a motion to move the case beyond Bangor, and his refusal to grant a mistrial after testimony that Cochran had been on parole.

Title: High court denies murder appeal Justices reject all three arguments made by Albert P. Cochran, convicted of slaying an Oakland nurse in 1976.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: The Maine Supreme Judicial Court on Friday denied the appeal of a Florida man convicted of killing a nurse who was raped and found shot to death in Norridgewock in 1976, a crime solved decades later by means of DNA evidence. After a nine-day jury trial last May, Albert P. Cochran, 61, of Stuart, Fla., was convicted of the murder of Janet Baxter, 30, of Oakland, who was abducted from a Waterville parking lot on Nov. 23, 1976. Her body was recovered from the trunk of a car found along the Kennebec River. He challenged his conviction on three issues: admissibility of hearsay testimony offered by the defense, the trial judge's denial of a motion to move the case beyond Bangor and his refusal to grant a mistrial following testimony that Cochran had been on parole.

Title: Action delayed on accused escapee Allegedly suicidal Bradley man set for sentencing on probation violation: [4th Edition]
Abstract: Brian Ouellette, 23, was scheduled to be sentenced Wednesday on a charge that he violated his probation. It also was expected that he may plead guilty to escape and possession of OxyContin, a narcotic drug. After Ouellette's release from prison on robbery charges, he violated his probation and served another year in jail. He was released from jail in 1998 and remained on probation. Earlier this spring he was arrested for possession of OxyContin and receiving stolen property. The new charges also resulted in another violation of probation charge.
Authors: Renee Ordway Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Stockholm man pleads not guilty Former Bay State probation officer charged with assault, witness tampering: [AROOSTOOK Edition]
Abstract: HOULTON -- A former Massachusetts probation officer, in a Maine prison for illegally possessing guns, loudly pleaded not guilty Thursday to additional charges of assault and tampering with a witness. Andrew Gerakaris, 48, of Stockholm appeared in Aroostook County Superior Court in Houlton for arraignment on the charges connected with an incident that occurred in December in the county jail. Appearing in dark blue pants and a striped shirt, Gerakaris stood beside his attorney, Richard Currier of Presque Isle, and answered "not guilty" in a loud voice as the court clerk read the charges during the Thursday hearing. Presiding was Justice Francis Marsano.
Authors: Debra Sund Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Briefly: [CITY Edition 1]
Abstract: The victim was identified as Pamela McAlevey, 69, a sister-in-law of state Rep. Michael McAlevey, R-Waterboro. She died at Maine Medical Center in Portland, where she'd been taken after the 9:15 a.m. crash. Police said the boy made a phone call to the high school shortly before 10 a.m. Thursday and warned that a gun was in the school. Police traced the call to a pay phone at a Scarborough Burger King. Police said the boy, already on probation with Juvenile Probation and Parole, admitted to making the call. Police took him to the Maine Youth Center.

Title: Letters to the editor: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: Imposing life sentences without the possibility of parole is a morally consistent way of punishing convicted murderers. The current debate about the death penalty needs to go beyond making sure that we are slaughtering only guilty people and move on to discuss what constitutes just justice. Beyond the fact that Hillary has been an excellent first lady and has had the poise to overcome the scandal of the presidency, she also managed to launch a campaign for health care reform and become one of the most mobile first ladies ever in her efforts to improve the nation's health care problems. Hillary Clinton's efforts to spread her vision of family values, along with bettering schools, improving health care and fighting for gun control has been a clear sign of her dedication to the bettering of lives for all Americans.

Title: Woman who started fire must stay out of Lincoln Probation includes following psychiatric treatment: [4th Edition]
Abstract: Justice Francis Marsano sentenced Melissa Hare to five years but suspended the prison term as part of an agreement reached between the Penobscot County District Attorney's Office and Hare's attorney, Deputy District Attorney Michael Roberts said.

Title: Cuban boy's relatives rebuff INS The lack of cooperation increases the likelihood Elian Gonzalez will be deported to Cuba, officials say.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: Miami relatives of 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez refused Tuesday to meet a key demand of federal immigration authorities, increasing the likelihood that the boy could be sent back to his father in Cuba, possibly within the next 48 hours. After meeting with Immigration and Naturalization Service officials here Tuesday morning, the relatives announced that they have not signed an agreement to surrender the boy should they lose their next court battle. In a letter late Monday, INS officials warned that they will terminate Gonzalez's temporary parole -- or permission to remain in the United States -- at 9 a.m. Thursday if the relatives do not give their written assurances on this point. They are challenging a ruling by U.S. District Judge K. Michael Moore in Miami, who last week upheld the INS decision to reunite Gonzalez with his father in Cuba.
Authors: SUE ANNE PRESSLEY and KAREN DEYOUNG The Washington Post

Title: U.S. says Cuban boy facing loss of parole The government wants a 'commitment' that Elian Gonzalez's relatives will comply with court rulings.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: The Justice Department said Monday night it would revoke Elian Gonzalez's parole to remain in the United States by Thursday unless his Miami relatives agree to promise to surrender the boy if they lose their court fight. The agency also said it has called the relatives to a meeting today to discuss the ramifications of the parole termination and an orderly return of the boy to his father in Cuba. The Immigration and Naturalization Service said it was not necessary to bring the 6-year- old Cuban boy to the meeting but that Lazaro Gonzalez, the boy's great-uncle, should attend. Attorney General Janet Reno has demanded that the relatives pursue any court appeals rapidly and promise to surrender Gonzalez for return to his father in Cuba if they lose.

Title: Employees lose round in fight for right to sue Despite a legislative committee's split vote, the bill's backers say they will continue to push for state workers' right to sue their boss. Series: STATE HOUSE 2000: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: State workers seeking protection under federal labor laws were dealt a setback by a legislative committee Friday. The Judiciary Committee voted unanimously to recommend paying $282,000 to a group of parole officers who were denied overtime pay in violation of the federal Fair Labor Standards Act, but split on granting state employees the general right to sue the state. The case is a result of a 1993 lawsuit by 92 probation officers who claimed they were denied overtime pay guaranteed to them by federal law. They were successful in court, but the decision was overturned on appeal by the U.S. Supreme Court, which ruled that although state workers are protected by federal statutes, states enjoy sovereign immunity, and cannot be sued in federal court.

Title: Baby-stealer sentenced for probation violation: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: BANGOR -- A Carmel woman who kidnapped a newborn baby from Eastern Maine Medical Center three years ago was sentenced Wednesday to spend 50 days in jail after violating her probation. Nicole Hartley, formerly known as Nicole Yablonka, appeared before Justice Andrew Mead in Penobscot County Superior Court. Hartley, 29, is on probation after serving six months in jail for snatching a sleeping newborn from the Bangor hospital Nov. 18, 1996. On that date, Hartley, dressed as a nurse, walked into the maternity ward at EMMC and took the 8-hour-old infant from his mother's arms.
Authors: Jeff Tuttle Of the NEWS Staff

Title: State workers seek right to sue employer Legislation that would help state probation officers could have far- reaching implications. Series: STATE HOUSE 2000: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: The bill seeks to pay overtime to 92 state probation officers, who won their case in court but saw the verdict overturned last year. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that a state cannot be sued without its consent because it enjoys sovereign immunity, a legal doctrine with roots in the idea that "The king can do no wrong." The bill would settle the probation workers' case, either by giving them the right to sue or by paying them what they would have won in court. But more troubling for lawmakers, it would also create a waiver of immunity for any state worker who, at any time in the future, would want to sue the state. "This is a real tough one," said Sen. Susan W. Longley, D- Liberty, co-chairman of the Judiciary Committee. "We are being asked to decide about some workers we don't even know about yet."

Title: More work needed at Bonny Eagle before probation can be lifted School officials put a positive spin on an accrediting agency report and say the high school should be off probation by 2002.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: Despite improvements in a range of areas, Bonny Eagle High School remains on probation with the New England Association of Schools and Colleges. In a letter released Monday, the director of the accrediting agency said that the school, which has been on probation since December 1997, has fixed three major problems, but still fails to meet standards in three other areas. "I am very pleased at the progress we have made," she said. "There are 10 standards, and out of the 10 standards, we were on probation for six. They have taken us off probation on three of those."

Title: Parole proposal rejected by legislative committee Current community release program supported: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: The retired schoolteacher found no believers on the Legislature's Criminal Justice Committee, which voted 8-0 Monday against [James] Skoglund's bill to reinstate parole. Five committee members were absent. Those members who voted against the bill favored expansion of the year-old supervised community release program instead of returning to the parole system that was rescinded in 1976. Only a handful of inmates at Maine State Prison remain eligible under the old parole program. Skoglund said the bill was inspired by the "Supermax" prison in Warren, where inmates are locked in their cells 23 hours a day. He argued that inmates need an incentive to start a program of self- improvement while they spend years in such a maximum security institution. Also, it is much less expensive to release an inmate on parole than pay the $25,000 to $30,000 a year cost to keep him behind bars, Skoglund reminded the committee.
Authors: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Prison inmate speaks for reinstating parole: [3rd Edition]
Abstract: A Maine State Prison inmate serving a 60-year sentence for murder urged legislators Thursday to reinstate parole even though he would not be eligible for release. On a hot summer night in 1986, Jeffrey Libby, 36, of Brooksville murdered his paternal grandfather by drowning him in the bathtub, he told the politicians. Rep. James Skoglund, D-St. George, is the sponsor of a bill to reinstate parole, which is now in the midst of the legislative process. Sen. Chellie Pingree, D-North Haven, and Rep. Judith Powers, D-Rockport, joined Skoglund at the prison meeting with Libby.
Authors: Leanne M. Robicheau Of the NEWS Staff

Title: Bill would reinstate parole Lawmaker says move would reduce costs, crowding: [ALL Edition]
Abstract: Resurrecting parole would be a more effective and less expensive way of deterring repeat offenses than the state prison system, according to a St. George Democrat. Rep. James Skoglund says resurrecting parole would allow the state to spend less while getting more. His bill would create a supervised release program for prisoners who have served most of their sentences and demonstrated an ability to return to society without breaking the law. If the bill becomes law, prisoners sentenced after it takes effect who have served more than half their time would be eligible for release. A parole board would review their cases, and those released would be supervised by parole officers.

Title: Bill seeks to bring parole back to Maine Proponents say it will save money and deter crime, but opponents maintain it doesn't work.: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: [James] Skoglund, D-St. George, wants the state to resurrect parole as a more effective and less expensive way of deterring repeat offenses than the current system of sending prisoners away for a set sentence. If the bill becomes law, prisoners sentenced after it takes effect who have served more than half their time would be reviewed by a parole board and be eligible for early release under the supervision of a parole officer. Parole would also save the state money, Skoglund says, by easing overcrowding in state prisons. That overcrowding has led the state to budget $68 million to build the new prison in Warren to house 1,000 prisoners.

Title: Thomas O. Mower Jr., 86: [CITY Edition]
Abstract: He worked at Pepperell Mill from 1932 to 1937. He then joined the Lewiston Fire Department, retiring as deputy chief in December 1962, when he became the first public safety director in Orono. In 1968, he joined the Maine Department of Mental Health and Corrections, Division of Probation and Parole, in Portland and Auburn. He retired as a probation and parole officer II in 1979.

Title: 2 teen girls charged in school bomb scare Pair suspended from PVHS, may be expelled: [4th Edition]
Abstract: HOWLAND -- The Penobscot County Sheriff's Department has charged two teen-age girls with terrorizing in connection with a Dec. 16 bomb scare at Penobscot Valley High School. Deputy Bill Flagg said the teens, a 17-year-old Enfield girl and a 16-year-old Burlington girl, were released to the custody of their parents under strict conditions, which include direct adult supervision. The deputy said the two teens would appear in Lincoln District Court some time in March. Early next week, he will meet with Juvenile, Probation and Parole to review the case.
Authors: Mary Anne Lagasse of the NEWS Staff
